movie_review_blurb: A British horror oddity like no other, now fully authorised.
an extraordinarily well made film that, in keeping us at a distance and failing to engage our sympathies or antipathies for its characters, remains more toothless in the end even than old Anse.

Sen... creates a Great Southern western, using the iconography of the oater to show the Australian landscape as something akin to the shifting boundaries (geographical, moral, racial) of America's wild, wild cowboy days

From its opening monochrome close-up of nine-year-old Addie Loggins at the barely attended outdoor funeral of her mother, Peter Bogdanovich's Depression-era road movie Paper Moon (1973) is dominated by the presence of Tatum O'Neal.

If perhaps not as frightening as the original, Insidious 2 certainly amps up the knowing hokiness (which was always at least a ghostly presence in the first film), while proving far bolder and more ingenious than your average sequel.
There is much craft on show in the technical aspects of this film's production, but like the traditional zombies at its core, The Dead 2: India is slow, sluggish and soulless
the film is so quick to get down to the nitty-gritty of the process that the spectacle of perforated and pulled flesh is fast normalised, losing its horror.

Yep, 'wither' must be Swedish for 'the evil dead', as this Nordic nasty slavishly drums out every beat of Sam Raimi's 1981 classic, positioning itself as unofficial 'premake' to Fede Alvarez's authorised reimagining Evil Dead (2013).

Gilliam appears to have become trapped in the loop of his own fantasy - although, as fantasies go, it is a good one, dark and despairing precisely because of its awareness that any hope is just part of the illusion.
by turns funny and frightening... a perfect hybridisation of familiar found footage tropes and transgressive Bobcattery.
despite the film's aqueous motifs of rain, showers, floods and tears, here in the end blood runs thicker than water.
for those who do not carp at the absence of a narrative hook, this synaesthetic ichthyo-apocalypse is oddly angled, intimately scaled and well worth catching.
keeps holding out a promise of insight into its young protagonist's mentality and makeup, but ends up merely observing her from a cool distance, as if through the binoculars from the opening scene.

Returning to the womb, raising the dead and playing with a long lost childhood friend - these are all apt metaphors for the nostalgia in which, like a comfort blanket for Satanic slumberers, The Demon's Rook wraps itself.

a hallucinatory trip through a cityscape of the imagination, it also allegorises our own very real relationship with the mythopoeic worlds of cinema (from which this film quotes with relentless, voracious postmodernism) or of the internet

Tilda Swinton and Tom Hiddleston may be decadent blood drinkers, but it is we mortals who are both mindless 'zombies' and a plague upon the world, while they are the keepers, curators and even contributors of... underground culture

It is this very understatement, and the weight given to Shin's words over any accompanying sound or image, that prevent Wiese's film ever seeming exploitative, even though it is addressing unimaginable human depravity and degradation.
a pleasingly surreal - if slightly hit-and-miss - sugar rush that younger viewers will swallow hook, line and sinker.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: a heady psychotropic stew of Mulholland Dr. (2001), Cure (1997) & Rabitto Hora 3D (2011), written with a tightness that, despite the disjointed style & damaged point-of-view, enables all the fractured narrative pieces eventually to fall into place.

while its machinery is all precisely calibrated, once the key has been found to its inner workings all ambiguity vanishes, and we are left merely to admire the convoluted, paradoxical intricacy of the clockwork.

...shows a clash of the middle & working classes, of city & village, of localism & internationalism, not to mention of men & women, with Amake's belly, whether bulging or padded, becoming a heavily contested arena for Nigeria's body politic.

despite some good performances, Side By Side is a meandering, overlong trek of a film, populated by broadly drawn and broadly unengaging characters, accompanied by irksome folk music, and padded out lazily with fart jokes.

Here working-class woes, Northern grimness and mucky miserabilism create a familiar Loachian vibe, as though all the magic and miracles of a children's fable had become mired in the realities of British life on the margins
On the basis of this elegiac family saga, Studio Ghibli should really think about hiring director Mamoru Hosoda.

This is a stilted, dreary film -- and pretty derivative.
The film is entirely disposable. Watching a group of teenagers "tongue their meds" (which does not mean doing something rude with a junior doctor) and sobbing out of windows is boring.
Brosnan's Bond looks like a man who actually has a wife and kids back home. He looks like he owns a juicer. But worse, we're now getting into Bond's mind, which is a dreadful cul-de-sac.
Piffle, really, with guitars.
The set-up is sometimes quite intriguing. Especially when it features Michael Fassbender as Magneto (massively magnetic).
Very few people can hit you in the thoracic cavity like Loach.
The style of the film is not teasing exactly -- it's too sad and lonely -- but there is certainly a hair-pulling mixture of glum laughter and vast apprehension. Is the demon real? Does it matter?

Hanks brings much interest to his laconic, bereft character, chasing the bird of happiness. He is quite the perfect actor to play an American suffering while the US is in economic decline - because he was such a star when it wasn't.
Pointedly droll.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You sit, smeary-faced, as Evans exhausts one cold-blooded hoodlum confrontation after another - in prisons, in restaurants, on the subway. It is so expertly played, it never becomes stupid ...
The film is just three degrees off being brilliant yet is always creepingly moving, and I loved its lived-in squalor.
It's undercooked (we're not even told what movies he loved as a child) and a clip of the great New Yorker critic Pauline Kael speaking made me sit bolt upright thinking "Now you're talking."
Such an astonishing, crucial life as Turing's deserves a more courageous, inventive film. Not this opportunistic, King's Speech -like Oscar grab.

Ultron is slyly funny. And it manages to balance this sort of comedy (I hooted when the Hulk listens to Maria Callas on headphones) with the tendency towards the sort of whacko-labyrinthine operatic complexity inherent in comic books.
Middle-class, very self-consciously egalitarian New Jersey is lucidly captured, especially the mildly daring dinner parties.
Calvary's gruelling central issue of abuse has been enough to quieten much criticism of the film, but in truth, most of the time it is coasting.
There is simply nothing more Hammer than Jared Harris in The Quiet Ones.
These appalling scenes aren't just memorably staged - also is their sense that as a species we might never be warm or clean again; that we are irrevocably smeared in leaf-mulch.
The chaotic story doesn't have much juice or spirit ...
It is a movie with a pace that never slackens, and yet still allows you to feel you're being given time to recollect, reflect, look about.
Nobly acted and always reaching for a dreamlike resonance, The Sea is an adaptation of John Banville's Man Booker Prize-winning novel - he also wrote the screenplay.
At 45, Moodysson is working completely without pessimism or sentimentality.
A suspense drama devoted to one fleeting moment of sub-thermocline narcolepsy. If nothing else, a first.
A marriage, a house and its rooms and sounds, and a move, all filmed in a manner that seems both improvised and relaxed while at the same time controlled and formal.
Vast, dark-dreamish, touching.
An empathetic, melancholy documentary about the photographer, now 89, who started on the paper in 1963 with an assignment to photograph Jean Cocteau.
The only part of [Depp] still genuinely dynamic is his hair. I'm worried.
A slapstick, glossy fantasy ...

Pantani's ebullience and delight in his own talent always come through - he still commands the sort of respect Lance Armstrong (who appears here now and again, at his most hubristic) can only dream of.
movie_title: Pantani: The Accidental Death Of A Cyclist (2014)

movie_review_blurb: We loll, longing for literally anything else. A movie about Stalin? The Foreign Legion? Donald Duck?
The franchise's new entry gives the sage a sense of what was missing in Chapter 4. [Full review in Spanish]
A conventional and conventional horror film that fails to highlight even the most conventional films of the genre. [Full review in Spanish]
A perfectly executed horror film that deals with primordial fears. [Full review in Spanish]
Apart from all the debatable elements of [Federico Felliní's] style, Satiricón is a totally recommendable movie. [Full review in Spanish]
The result is rather mediocre... [Full review in Spanish]
movie_title: Malpertuis: The Legend of Doom House (1971)

movie_review_blurb: The development is solid... with the almost constant presence of an ironic Humphrey Bogart, perfectly aware of his fullness as an actor. [Full review in Spanish]
... does not delve into its possibilities... only seems to show us the horrible side of reality. [Full review in Spanish]
Disturbingly powerful visual effects and a dark background score add to the film's appeal.
The journey is not powerful enough. It loses track and seems purposeless soon enough.

A couple of over-the-top sequences aside, Vishwaroopam is a work of art that surpasses Bollywood potboilers and tries to initiate a conversation about a not-so-perfect world and its great religious divide.

I simply didn't want to be subjected to the ugliness anymore. Which is a shame because Lakshmi is heartfelt and has some fine performances by Monali, Kaushik and Shah. I can't wholeheartedly recommend Lakshmi. It's repulsive, yet demands to be seen.
It's innocuous candyfloss.

If I sound like a woman cheated, it's only because I was so invested in Reema Kagti's suspense drama. The film has one of the most terrific first hours I've seen this year. It's taut, twisty and absolutely thrilling.
In Luck by Chance, Zoya, a first time director but a second generation industry insider, takes us on a beguiling journey into this world.
How much you enjoy Ready is directly proportionate to your affection for Salman and cheerfully cheesy, low-brow humour.
Katrina is gorgeous and Akshay Kumar strains every muscle in his body to make you laugh. But the lazy writing does them in.
I recommend that you see the film for the sheer pleasure of watching Salman Khan in top form.
It is so fantastically ridiculous that you have to ask - what have we -- enthusiastic, loyal, passionate lovers of Hindi cinema -- done to deserve this?
The narrative becomes melodramatic and even more synthetic as Punit tries to inject emotion and a sense of nobility that hasn't been earned.
When I walk into a film called Agent Vinod, what I want, more than anything else, is an adrenalin rush... The plot plods along, especially in the first half.
It has technical pizzazz and an urbane wit despite snags like sub-plots with pat endings.
Kai Po Che! is a moving portrait of friendship, loss, forgiveness.
Potent but problematic.
Special 26 is the best Hindi film I've seen this year.
Audacious, original and absolutely gut-wrenching.
The assured direction and writing are bolstered by wonderful performances.
I can guarantee that the next time you see a horde of screaming fans, you'll observe them more keenly. You might even wonder what their stories are.
We get to know these people. We start to care about them -- especially Suraj.
Sultan is an overwrought, overblown, over-stretched sports saga. When it ended, I had moist eyes and a big grin on my face. In wrestling terms, it's an over-sized Salman slam.
The film feels overly ceremonious, purposefully epic and, in places, a little exhausting. But hang in there. Because slowly and skillfully, Bajirao Mastani transports you.
It breaks my heart to say this because so much talent and sweat is involved, but Mohenjo Daro is a mess.

The screenplay lurches randomly, eventually leading to a climax so convoluted and false that much of the affection I had for Sid and Trisha evaporated. Which is such a shame because until then, I was having so much fun.
I walked out of this film wiping away tears and feeling invincible. I felt I could wrestle down anything that hit me. How do you put a rating on that?
Way too much time and effort is spent showcasing the leading man -- John's body is a no-carb miracle and Kamat fetishises it.
Dear Zindagi is a bumpy ride but, all things considered, it's still one worth taking -- especially for the sheer pleasure of watching Alia soar.
My Name is Khan is on firm footing as long as director Karan Johar stays with emotional drama.

I totally believe that John Abraham can lift a car or crush dozens of men with his bare hands even when he has a long metal nail embedded in his shoulder... It's the rest of the film that is difficult to process.
This is the cinematic equivalent of junk food -- when you walk in, you know exactly what you're going to get.

This is a film made with love, bolstered by wonderfully etched vignettes, Ranbir Kapoor's stupendous performance and a gorgeous soundtrack by Pritam. And yet, for me, Barfi was a singularly frustrating experience.

It's fascinating to see Byomkesh evolve as the case does. He sees the heart of darkness and emerges wiser, more mature and, ironically, a tad more joyful. It's a demanding role and Sushant Singh Rajput more than delivers.
Ungli is a half-baked, laughably simplistic drama about a gang of do-gooders who decide, and I quote here, to show the system the finger.
So does Dhoom:3 deliver? Yes and no.
It breaks my heart to tell you that Chennai Express left me cold.
There is a hushed wisdom in this film. Find it.
Gritty is not the adjective that comes to mind when you think of director Pradeep Sarkar or producer Yash Raj Films. So the first few minutes of Mardaani are startling.
It is frantic, noisy, gaudy and, largely, joyless.
Perhaps Gadhvi decided that style and glamour are enough to render narrative inconsequential. The actors pout and preen but are bleached into the background by Roshan's high-beam star power.
And after the first 10 minutes, I was utterly bowled over by Dhanush's energy and charm.

This uneasy mix of truth and creative license; subtle notes and heavy-handedness make for an uneven film... That said, No One Killed Jessica is several notches ahead of the tripe we've been subjected to in theatres lately.
Tevar is tiring, predictable, and largely banal.
A throwback to what Hindi films used to be: a three hour extravaganza of romance, comedy, action, set-piece songs and drama.
Filmmaker Rakesh Roshan deserves a round of applause for giving us a homegrown superhero. Krrish 3 is ambitious and exciting. Sadly, it's also derivative, clumsy, convoluted and far too long.
In Margarita with a Straw, writer-director Shonali Bose and actor Kalki Koechlin give us a woman we have never seen in our cinema before.

Bombay Talkies is a unique experiment that works very well. The collaboration between four leading directors suggests a confidence that was rare in the industry even a decade ago. I believe that things can only get better from here on.
Bullett Raja is essentially a crackling character in search of a story.
Of course it's played out like a comic book but if you're willing to suspend disbelief there's fun to be had.
I strongly recommend that you see Robot, to partake in writer-director Shankar's prodigious imagination and to revel in the sheer force of nature that is Rajinikanth.
I didn't buy into the story, but I bought into the heartfelt performances.
Rowdy Rathore beats you to a pulp, cinematically. It's a relentless assault that kicks in as soon as the credit titles roll.
For Salman Khan fans, it's manna from heaven... Those who like a coherent narrative and dramatic arc, though, won't enjoy the ride so much.
Too often, [director Anu] Menon resorts to formulaic character traits, so if Nikhil is a pretentious film school student, he must have a goatee and refer to Andrei Tarkovsky.
Even if you're willing to ignore the logic-free story and buy heavily into the cult of Bhai, Kick is bumpy, and far too convoluted to deliver the joyride of a Dabangg.
In all honesty, I'm confused about how to evaluate Jai Ho. Because it's not a film. It's a cartoon.
[Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani] liberally echoes DDLJ and every other major romance to come out of Bollywood in the last two decades.
Director Tinu Suresh Desai's take on this landmark crime is flat and uninspired.
Vishwaroop has to be admired for its scale and ambition.
As the story unravels, the direction becomes more heavy-handed too.
Editor Namrata Rao keeps the pace breathless -- there isn't a wasted frame or moment.
The curse of the second half strikes so badly in this film that it almost completely negates the first half.
OK Jaanu isn't a bad film. It's just a pointless one. Because an exact -- and I mean frame-for-frame -- version already exists in Tamil.
This is an uneven film. In places, you will applaud and whistle. But you might also find yourself utterly exhausted.

Kaabil is a B-grade genre film elevated by the blazing talent of its lead player -- Hrithik Roshan. Hrithik invests so much sweat and sincerity in this slim story that he forces us to stay invested in it.
Once in a while I see a film that is hypnotic in its awfulness; which means it's so bad that you can't look away. Kung Fu Yoga is one such film.
Sadly, this one has too few laughs and not enough meat.
Himesh [Reshammiya] and director Shawn Arranha really let me down.
Dil Bole Hadippa is worth seeing for the sweetness and charm that Rani Mukherjee and Shahid Kapur conjure up.
movie_title: Dil Bole Hadippa! (My Heart Goes Hooray!) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Karnik is a fine technician who has taken care to dress each frame. What rankles is what might have been.
Budhia Singh's story stays with you. The anguish is authentic. Which makes the film worth your time.

What is a brahmarakshas? According to Creature 3D, it's a cross between a lizard and a dinosaur, with a splash of Davy Jones from Pirates of the Caribbean thrown in. It is also one of the many reasons why this is one of those supremely foolish films.
Daawat-e-Ishq is the equivalent of an elaborate meal that begins with a mouth-watering appetiser but slowly loses flavour, aroma and deliciousness.
There is enough pep in Fukrey to make it pleasantly diverting. I'm not suggesting that you drop everything and get to the theatre. But if you happen to stroll in, you are likely to come out smiling.
The characters in Tum Bin II are ready to impart life lessons anytime, anywhere.

Filmistaan is a delightful film. It has heart, imagination and intelligence. It is a celebration of our enduring love affair with Hindi cinema. And it is a touching exploration of the shared humanity between Indians and Pakistanis.
Jolly LLB is a feel-good satire in the best sense of the term.

This film would be dead on arrival without the energy of the male leads - even when they are hamming, and they ham often, they are doing it with glorious style. Of the three stars for Gunday, one is for Ranveer and Arjun.

The film, however, never becomes more than the sum of its parts. Aashiqui 2 falls into that lukewarm category of 'I didn't mind it,' which is not the same as 'I liked it.' It could have been so much more.
This might just be the most unwatchable Bollywood film of the year.

There is much to admire here: the film is beautifully shot by Sudeep Chatterjee. It has strong performances and there are several scenes which genuinely move you. But there is just as much that is clumsy.
Hunterrr runs for 141 minutes and feels even longer. That's just way too much time to spend on the life and emotions of a lech.
While Hawaa Hawaai isn't entirely satisfying, I still recommend that you see it. It is a timely reminder of the intractable horrors that children in this country face on a daily basis.
Kaalakaandi is trippy, cheerfully absurd and in places, laugh-out-loud funny.
After watching Khiladi 786 - close on the heels of that other mind-numbing action-comedy, Son of Sardaar - I think it's time for Bollywood to give Punjab a little rest.
I'm thrilled to report that with Befikre, Aditya Chopra reinvents himself. And in doing so, he gives Bollywood romance a buoyancy and exhilaration.
Neeraj Pandey's telling of Dhoni's life is in equal parts, thrilling, moving and utterly exhausting.
Even in the context of Shetty's oeuvre, Dilwale is a low. It made me nostalgic for Chennai Express.
Writer-director Abhishek Dogra and co-writer Umashankar Singh take a somewhat silly story, add crackling dialogue and sharp characters, and serve up dollops of laughs.
Shujaat is clearly not a big believer in the classic writing rule: Show, don't tell.
Director Leena Yadav, who has also written the story, has etched these women with great affection and compassion.
Housefull 3 is about three Indian heiresses in London. Don't ask me what their names are. These aren't characters. They are props.
Dishoom is a silly but fun reworking of the time-tested buddy cop formula.
Jadhav's unique voice gets flattened out quickly. The culprits are a convoluted, over-stuffed storyline, excessive visual razzmatazz, and an uneven soundtrack.
Even the most ardent Sid and Kat fans will find it difficult to stay interested.
UnIndian has stray moments of warmth and humour, but it's just not enough. I am interested to see what Mr. Lee does next, though.
Honestly, I don't remember the last time I cried so much in a film.
A Flying Jatt could have been a fun entertainer with mum as the moral centre. Instead, it is just exhausting.
Baaghi: A Rebel for Love is a mostly ridiculous film powered by the poetry of Tiger Shroff.
It's only January but I'm willing to bet good money that Bollywood won't make a worse film than Mastizaade this year.
If nothing else, see it to see what Akshay Kumar can do.
From this solid material, director Omung Kumar fashions a film that is structurally clumsy and overtly high-pitched but also strongly enacted and genuinely moving.

One of the enduring problems with Balki's films persists -- his crackling concept runs out of steam. It's almost as if he spends so much of his creative energy coming up with the high-wire idea that he has none left to flesh out the narrative around it.
Ultimately, Jai Gangaajal is too familiar to be engaging or essential.
It's an old-fashioned fight between good and evil but what makes it gripping is the determination and earnestness that Sunny Deol brings to it.
Pink is a powerful film that deserves to be seen. Make time for it.
Aligarh isn't just a fine film. It's also important, necessary and timely. It will shift something inside you.

Ankhon Dekhi is a delicate and delightful film about invisible people -- those ordinary folk you pass on the street but rarely pay attention to. Writer-director Rajat Kapoor finds beauty and richness in their lives.
The disjointed narrative brims with low-IQ high-testosterone men brandishing weapons. The women are puppets who either simper or scream.
Bajrangi Bhaijaan is simplistic, occasionally silly, and tiringly over-stretched. It's also unashamedly manipulative. But it works.
Cocktail is a fun, romantic romp.
The set-up and characters are promising but Sulemani Keeda never becomes more than the sum of its parts because it's too thin.
Painfully affected and spectacularly tedious.
Khoobsurat is sweet, benign, and bland.
The factors that work in favour of Bombay Velvet outnumber those that do not. For one, Kashyap elicits fairly restrained performances from most of the cast.
There are occasional CGI disasters, most notably during the movie's rushed climax, but the film mostly makes for a rewarding visual experience.
Unlike the man himself, the movie does not impress for any stretch of time.
A dud with a clumsy, superficial take on grim social issues.
The movie also lasts far longer than it should.

The tragedy of Hamari Adhuri Kahaani, like so many movies before it, is that it turns out looking and sounding so stupid. It could have worked if only the director had taken the effort to de-clutter it.
It's a bright and enjoyable tale, well told and beautifully performed -- so good that, at times, you forget it's animated at all.
Anyone criticizing the gruesome bloodlust of modern Hollywood might do well to ponder the body count in this play...
It is an entertainment and quite a good one too.
While the film maintains a strong moral centre and never attempts to replicate the savage reality of such a situation, it still might be a little too scary for young audiences.
The approach may be highly original, just as the ingredients are familiar but Helgeland has fashioned a delicious new recipe from them.
Overall the 3D adventure bears a polish that reflects a sophisticated set of production values but which the scriptwriting and increasingly banal characterisations have not kept up with.
A botched adventure that looks suspiciously like any number of other sci-fi tales you will have seen, and pales instantly by the comparison.
Violence always involves moral questions, and the decision whether to take up armed struggle lies at the heart of revolutionary movements, but the film does not take these concerns at all seriously.

It celebrates Simons' vision, but, more interestingly, also reveals to viewers the busy, hierarchical world of the atelier, where dozens of highly skilled craftspeople, headed by a workshop première, labour for long hours on a collection.
The film hits some obvious notes, and some sentimental ones, but it also surprises
What the film and its characters convey to us, cumulatively, is a struggle for and towards dignity.

Gone Girl fails as a crime thriller in part because it is far too long - none of Fincher's major feature films have clocked in at less than two hours, and several run closer to three - but mostly because the distribution of its sympathies are so uneven.
Tom Hardy gives a bravura performance.
Listen Up Philip [is] an uneven mixture of satire and homage.

Boyhood never allows itself to be trivial - we never see anyone buying groceries, or picking their nose, or spending their days tied to a job they don't enjoy. It's a film that's being celebrated as a triumph of realism, but it isn't like real life at all
All Is Lost is a testament to the possibilities of digital cinema: a film like this, shot in such close confines, simply couldn't be made with anything other than lightweight, handheld cameras.

The achievement of [Ron] Howard's documentary is to make the familiar feel new again, placing the viewer inside that moment - even if you never lived it - when to witness The Beatles was to watch the horizon of your world brighten before you like the dawn
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Wes Anderson's] nostalgia, like his set design, is so contrived that I don't believe he really believes in it as anything other than a visual style. The Grand Budapest Hotel is a perfect miniature world, but it left me cold.
Kermit [the Frog] embodies the strange magic of puppetry. He's human and animal; real and make-believe; an avatar for the joyous, unfettered imagination that [Jim] Henson brought into the world.
Scenes transparently designed to sweep an audience away with the power of music falter, because the songs are weak. But the young cast do look the part.
Newcastle-born stand-up comedian Dave Johns plays this largely non-comedic part with understated warmth.

It is tempting to call it a universal story, a timeless story, but this is too comforting, too glib.It is a specific story, of being queer, black and poor in America - still a story that is little told onscreen.

It will stand alongside the similarly epic Hoop Dreams as a documentary that, with sport as its ostensible subject, also serves as an examination of race in America, and of fame's perverse and distorting effects.

[Kelly] Reichardt's characters are not taken from comic books; they are not easy heroes or outsize villains. [They] are the kind who drive second-hand cars or catch the bus. Their lives seem beyond their own ability to command, but they are not meaningles
As a whole it's worth savouring.
It's a worthwhile field of enquiry, made into a strangely self-satisfied film.
Why craft a subtle emotional cue when, with overpowering string instruments and the ubiquitous sonic boom, you can prevent an audience from thinking at all?

Though it is doubtful that [Nina] Simone, were she still alive, would be much impressed with [Kanye] West's music - she once said that she didn't like rap at 'all' - she might recognise in him a fellow spirit.

Felony is too close to generic; another story about gruff Australian coppers, and god knows we've had plenty of those. As the moral stakes increased for Mal and his colleagues I found it difficult to care, because I felt as if I'd seen it all before
The bravery and the radicalism was real. I wish, though, that the film itself was a little braver, a little more visceral.
Spectre is an elaborate justification for the relevance of the gun-toting, martini-drinking spy in a post-Snowden world.
The emotional stakes are lowered in Lanthimos's world, but the operation of power is much the same as it ever was.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Love and Friendship is very funny, funnier still for its absence of moral reckoning.

High-Rise has no shortage of vivid images to tempt the eager filmmaker, from a ransacked supermarket to an Afghan hound floating dead in a swimming pool. What's harder to convey is that distinctive Ballardian tone.
Though A United Kingdom has an emotional arc that is too predictable, its resurrection of a widely forgotten piece of twentieth-century history is worthy.
[Michelle] Williams has only a few scenes but makes her mark in all of them.
The naïveté of the main character feels far less credible.
Things to Come is a rare and welcome film for not suggesting that a woman is unnatural or unfeeling to care for her work as much as for her family.
A Quiet Passion, like most films about writers, sticks to the life that can be dramatised, rather than the writing process, which can't.
[Francis] Lee allows more optimism into his film, including the suggestion that agriculture itself might still have a future in England.
First time writer-director Greta Gerwig, an experienced actor, is attuned to the mix of munificence and selfishness that makes up the adolescent heart.
Selma gives back to the Civil Rights movement its urgent and motivating anger, when too often the movement has been misrepresented as a cause of infinitely patient, infinitely forbearing martyrs.
In [Jennifer] Peedom's film we see a mountain that is both workplace and sacred site, integral to both the economic livelihood and the religious beliefs of the surrounding Sherpa community.
If there is any heroism in Spotlight then it's a very humble one: the heroism of getting the facts right, which seems, today, almost too much to ask of mainstream newspapers.
The Gift is efficiently and quite memorably chilling.
This is a Macbeth that retains Shakespeare's language but makes free and easy with edits, rearrangements, and a few bold reinterpretations of key scenes.
A Most Violent Year is uneven in pace and tone, as events threaten to erupt and then simmer down again, but despite its flaws, it lingers in the mind.
Borrow a young relative for cover if you must, but believe me, you are not too cool for a kid's movie when it's this much fun.
It Follows is unnerving without being bloody, and more than this, that it cleverly inverts the sexual politics on which so much popular culture, most especially the horror film, often depends.
New Yorkers love nothing more than a story about themselves.

A Girl Walks Home Alone At Night deftly mixes genre tropes while creating its own singular, surreal universe. I've never seen another a film where a female vampire dressed in a chador rides a skateboard, that's for sure.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Smug, sanitized fantasy, in which the hysterical blonde attention-seeker, in a succession of sparkly outfits, is uprooted from New York to the boring suburbs and learns boring suburban values like telling the truth.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Grainy video and gimmicky editing give this documentary an amateurish feel, but Samir's charming, rueful interlocutors shine through.
movie_title: Forget Baghdad: Jews and Arabs - The Iraqi Connection (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Rand (John Livingston), who looks like a hangdog Ben Affleck, and the believably vulnerable Sarah (Sabrina Lloyd) make awkward reticence appealing.
A sanitized adventure for the Mary Kate-and-Ashley set.
The three move through a faded deck of clichés ... with a convincing impression of having fun, helped along by a snazzy '60s-'70s soundtrack and bit-part fillips.
As far as practical effects go, Graveyard Shift is an underappreciated treat for gorehounds.
Surely a special treat for Chicagoans and marathoners alike, especially for how it provides a human face for one of the city's major annual highlights.
This excellent documentary on Alberto K. Fujimori serves as a cautionary essay on the risks to democracy posed by the fight against terrorism.
Albert Brooks takes his anxious, cerebral act on the road, to India and Pakistan. There's great satiric potential, but most of it is squandered after a hilarious opening.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This documentary about the pioneering black filmmaker Melvin Van Peebles is nearly as mischevious and fascinating as its subject.
movie_title: How to Eat Your Watermelon in White Company (And Enjoy It) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Not a movie version of the book but rather a movie about a movie about the book.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Takes place at the particular intersection of reality and fantasy defined by youthful moviegoing.
movie_title: The Spirit of the Beehive (El Espíritu de la colmena) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A lavish spectacle somewhere between grand opera and cartoon about a love triangle involving a general, a slave and a cursed princess.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Terry Zwigoff and Daniel Clowes plod through a grouchy attack on and example of the pretense and hypocrisy of self-declared artists.
Just My Luck is a bit of lukewarm cappuccino froth confected to float Lindsay Lohan to the next stage of her career.
The chief virtue of Wolfgang Petersen's reasonably well-executed remake of The Poseidon Adventure is that it keeps the action moving.
The film, while hardly unbiased, is not entirely one-sided.
A marvelously overripe 1922 silent melodrama starring Gloria Swanson and Rudolph Valentino.
Sketches of Frank Gehry respects the essential enigma of its subject even as it illuminates his ways of thinking about form, space and construction.

... Mr. Howard and Mr. Goldsman handle the supposedly provocative material in Mr. Brown's book with kid gloves, settling on an utterly safe set of conclusions about faith and its history, presented with the usual dull sententiousness.
An Inconvenient Truth is a necessary film.
Dominik Moll imbues the first half of his thriller with inklings of strangeness that are at once sinister and quietly comical. But there is, in the end, less to this film than meets the eye.
Marco Turco's meticulous and angry documentary examines the effects of Mafia power on Sicilian society and on Italian political life in the 1980s and early 90s.
Vince Vaughn and Jennifer Aniston play a couple on the splits in a desultory modern version of the classic comedies of remarriage of the 1930's and 40's.
Overlord, a prize-winning entry in the 1975 Berlin Film Festival, deserves to join the pantheon of essential World War II combat movies.
Directed by the prolific François Ozon, Time to Leave stars Melvil Poupaud as a fashion photographer facing the certainty that his life will soon be over.
This season's obligatory inspirational coach-centered sports movie finds its true story at a point where sports history intersects with the struggle for racial equality.
Although there are memorable bits and pieces, the new Pirates of the Caribbean is a movie with no particular interest in coherence, economy or feeling.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Takashi Miike's excursion into extravagant and demented fantasy combines folkloric elements with images from contemporary Japanese popular culture.
Meryl Streep inspires both terror and a measure of awe as the imperious editor of a glossy fashion magazine in the screen version of Lauren Weisberger's best-selling novel.
Whatever your opinion of the Iraq war, Deborah Scranton's documentary is sure to challenge your thinking and disturb your composure.
Like many feature films based on small-screen, short-form comedy, Strangers With Candy feels more like a long, sloppy 'very special' episode than a movie.
The Road to Guantanamo, based on the testimony of three British Muslims captured in Afghanistan in 2001, is a wrenching and dismaying account of cruelty and bureaucratic indifference.
Waist Deep is unapologetically a B movie, its narrative premise placed carefully on the borderline between the wildly implausible and the completely absurd.
The movie turns out to be a predictable and somewhat sentimental lower-depths love triangle, but Ms. Braga almost makes it work.
Neither an exposé of social conditions nor a psychological case study and certainly not a moral parable G. W. Pabst's Pandora's Box is a tour de force of cinematic eroticism.
There is still chemistry between Sandra Bullock and Keanu Reeves, but a heavy dose of Hollywood metaphysics keeps them apart for most of this wondrously illogical time-travel romance.
A late, minor addition to the Robert Altman collection but a treasure all the same A Prairie Home Companion is more likely to inspire fondness than awe.
Danny Leiner's film offers a collection of quiet, tidy vignettes that occur simultaneously in New York City a year after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
I did manage to be more tickled than annoyed at some of the movie's dumb, crude attempts at humor.
A complex, intriguing narrative about oil, terrorism, money and power.
If it does nothing else, Stryker, a grim little gang melodrama directed by Noam Gonick, might dispel some American assumptions about life in Canada.
Jacques Richard's affectionate documentary makes a persuasive case for Henri Langlois as one of the most important figures in the history of film.
movie_title: Henri Langlois: The Phantom of the Cinematheque (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Taking up the divided, anxious state of post-9/11 American life, Wim Wenders's new film is like a clumsy, well-meaning intervention in a family quarrel.
Cameron Crowe's tale of romance and redemptions struggles to sustain a tone of bittersweet whimsy, but its emotions are in the end as undercooked as its ideas.
This tight, sober and strangely comical new film from South Korea tells a tale that may sound far-fetched, but that is all the more crazy for being true.
Shane Black's film noir is a movie with no particular reason for existing, a flashy, trifling throwaway whose surface cleverness masks a self-infatuated credulity.
Shopgirl, written by Steve Martin, based on his slender novel of the same name, is an elegant and exquisitely tailored romantic comedy.
Yes, Dreamer follows a formula, but the formula, when applied with skill and intelligence, as it is here, is pretty much foolproof.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Ballets Russes, a graceful and fascinating documentary, chronicles the world of dance following the 1929 death of the ballet impresario Serge Diaghilev.
[Thurman's] summery radiance helps make this thin romantic comedy hard to dislike.
The first computer-animated film from Disney also has the distinction of being a terrible movie a hectic, uninspired pastiche of catch phrases and cliches.
Jarhead is a movie that walks up to some of the most urgent and painful issues of our present circumstance, clears its throat loudly and says nothing.
Lew Wasserman, who rose from the streets of Cleveland to become the most powerful man in Hollywood, is the subject of this absorbing documentary.
movie_title: The Last Mogul (Life and Times of Lew Wasserman) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Jim Sheridan's film, loosely based on the experiences of its star, the glowering rapper 50 Cent, lacks an emotional core.
Sarah Silverman is a skilled performer, and Jesus Is Magic is occasionally very funny, but don't be fooled: naughty as she may seem, she's playing it safe.
Johnny Cash gets the musical biopic treatment in this moderately entertaining, never quite convincing chronicle of his early years.
In his latest foray into the realm of the supernatural, M. Night Shyamalan turns an artful gothic tale into a homework assignment.
Claude Sautet's Classe Tous Risques is the kind of French movie that makes you want to throw on your trench coat, light up a cigarette and shoot somebody.
[Allen's] most satisfying film in more than a decade ...
Buried deep inside this misbegotten comedy is the glimmer of an idea.
Tempting as it is to dismiss Cache as a liberal guilt trip in the guise of a thriller, it is at the same time hard to deny its creepy, insinuating power.
Lasse Hallstrom's tale of an uncomplicated lover is a delightful respite from awards-season seriousness.
Uma Thurman as a would-be actress is the one bit of genuine radiance in this aggressively and pointlessly shiny, noisy spectacle.
Peter Jackson's remake is as much a tribute to the old, seat-of-the-pants spirit of early motion pictures as it is an exercise in technological bravura.
Lajos Koltai's film, which follows a Jewish boy from Budapest to Buchenwald, ranks among the best nondocumentary cinematic treatments of the Holocaust yet produced.
For Japanese horror aficionados only, and even they are likely to be underwhelmed by this stew of half-baked ideas and creepy sensations.
This honorable adaptation of C. S. Lewis's novel has much of the power and charm of the source.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Aeon Flux is best appreciated for the costumes, the sets and Charlize Theron's haughty athleticism.
Transamerica, starring Felicity Huffman as a pre-operative transsexual, is touching and sometimes funny, despite its overall air of indie earnestness.
One of the spooky archetypes of childhood imagination the dark, mysterious house across the street is literally brought to life in this marvelously creepy animated feature.
Chris Columbus's film affirms that Rent belongs in the pantheon of immortal musicals celebrating the self-dramatizing and resilient spirit of youth.
If you see only one documentary about a Slovene philosopher this year, it will most likely be Astra Taylor's brisk little film Zizek!
A sprawling, intellectually ambitious documentary about the political phenomenon usually referred to in journalistic shorthand as the war on terror.
movie_title: Power of Nightmares: The Rise of the Politics of Fear (2004)

movie_review_blurb: What makes Clerks II both winning and (somewhat unexpectedly) moving is its fidelity to the original Clerks ethic of hanging out, talking trash and refusing all worldly ambition.
... best viewed as an investigation of the phenomenon of ideological celebrity, with Mr. Franken as a willing case study.
The Ant Bully, the latest computer-animated plea for interspecies understanding, provides a few moments of inventiveness and wit.
Steve Anderson's rowdy and contentious new documentary pits the upholders of propriety against the proponents of free expression in a battle over just one word.
The film adaptation of Eric Schlossers best-selling book is far too rich and complicated to be understood as a simple, high-minded polemic.
With Bobby, Emilo Estevez tries to link the intimate stories of nearly two dozen characters to a large and consequential public event the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy.
The world of The Aura is, quite obviously, a heightened and stylized version of reality, but its governing emotions of dread, suspicion and moral confusion are bracingly real.
In his third feature, Darren Aronofsky tries to replace the prose of narrative cinema with a poetic language of rhyming images and visual metaphors.
Mr. Broderick and Mr. DeVito look tired and out of sorts, and you can hardly blame them, given the picture's inept, curdled mixture of sappiness and crude humor.
... The Nativity Story sticks to the familiar details of the narrative and dramatizes them with sincerity and good taste.
Brad Silberling's new movie has nothing to prove, and not all that much to say, but its modesty and good humor make it hard to resist.
Algeria's official Oscar submission for best foreign language film is a damn good war movie.
Mel Gibson's Apocalypto is, above all, a muscular and kinetic action movie, a drama of rescue and revenge with very little organic relation to its historical setting.
Not for the faint of heart, the movie is unsettling and startlingly true to life.
Audiences who go to Dreamgirls will have a good time, but theyll be going for old times sake rather than to encounter anything vital or new.
Gary Winick's film may not be perfect, but it honors its source and captures the key elements that have made E. B. White's book a classic.
Another masterwork from Clint Eastwood's astonishing late period, and one of the best war movies ever.
A modest, diverting, touching tale of a young woman who attracts the interest of an aging actor, played with effortless aplomb by the great Peter O'Toole.
Try as it might to be refined and provocative, Tom Tykwer's Perfume never rises above the pedestrian creepiness of its conceit.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Pan's Labyrinth is a political fable in the guise of a fairy tale. Or maybe it's the other way around.

With another actor in the title role (Kevin Costner, say, just off the top of my head) the mawkishness would be unbearable, but Mr. Thornton can be relied upon for understated dignity accompanied by an intriguing undertone of serious craziness.
Music and Lyrics aspires to nothing more than the competent dispensing of mild amusement and easy emotion.
Bamako is a work of cool intelligence and profound anger, a long, dense, argument that is also a haunting visual poem.
Too many of the gags in the sloppy comedy Norbit are lumbering and graceless, more fun to anticipate than to witness.
The Lives of Others is a supremely intelligent, unfailingly honest look at a shadowy period in recent German history.
Because I Said So is an exercise in deliberate mediocrity, with chuckles and heartwarming moments distributed as carefully as nuts in a factory-made brownie.
While Stranger Than Fiction traffics in a bit of darkly funny existential anxiety, it also finds room for romantic fantasy and sentimental uplift.
The documentary An Unreasonable Man is an admiring but hardly uncritical portrait of Ralph Nader and his 2000 presidential campaign.
Smokin Aces is a Viagra suppository for compulsive action fetishists and a movie that may not only be dumb in itself, but also the cause of dumbness in others.

Breaking and Entering climaxes in a welter of apologies. Everyone in London, it seems, has cause for remorse and for my part I regret that I lost count of the number of times the words 'I'm sorry' were uttered on screen.
2 or 3 Things I Know About Him offers an unusually matter-of-fact picture of the private and public effects of ordinary evil.
movie_title: Two or Three Things I Know About Him (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Primeval is one of several recent movies to bill itself as 'inspired by true events.' So was this review, though in both cases 'inspired' may be too strong a word.
There may be crazier movies than this Thai cowboy melodrama of betrayal and forbidden love, but I can't think of one that is quite so mad about its own craziness.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Comedy of Power is not Claude Chabrol's deepest or most ambitious film, but Isabelle Huppert's ferocity compensates for the director's detachment.
Thankfully, the crude, scatological parody Epic Movie, unlike the movies it sends up, is short.
James Longley's haunting, oblique film, Iraq in Fragments, presents a collage of images, sounds and characters in an intimate, partial portrait of an unraveling nation.
The first computer-animated feature to come from Aardman Animations is filled with exuberant and infectious silliness.
Pedro Almodóvar has made yet another picture that moves beyond camp into a realm of wise, luxuriant humanism.
... sometimes feels like an entire season of a television series crammed into less than two hours, full of activity, but lacking shape.
Makes the case that, in just about every way that counted, Lennon was a better person than Richard M. Nixon.
The stop-motion pooch and his cheese-loving master return in a silly and sublime feature-length adventure.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: That Rocco DeLuca and the Burden are attached to Kiefer Sutherland is the only discernible reason for the existence of Manu Boyer's inconsequential documentary.
movie_title: I Trust You to Kill Me (2006)

movie_review_blurb: What distinguishes the film from its many peers is the quality of Ms. Collyer's writing -- which rarely reaches for obvious, melodramatic beats -- and the precision of Ms. Gyllenhaal's performance.
This modest documentary examines the lives of a group of transsexual Philippine immigrants who work as home attendants for elderly Israelis and also perform in Tel Aviv nightclubs.
Like Y Tu Mamá También, Alfonso Cuaróns first feature, made 15 years ago, is a rambunctious sex comedy shadowed by mortality.
The Wicker Man is comically inept as a horror movie, unable to even manage an effective false scare, or sustain suspense for more than a beat or two.
Hans Canosa's studied debut feature stars Aaron Eckhart and Helena Bonham Carter as old flames who meet, years after parting, and have a short fling.
Beautifully shot in a sandy, remote corner of Northern Brazil, this lovely film tells the story of three generations of women.
Oliver Stone has taken a public tragedy and turned it into something at once genuinely stirring and terribly sad.

The Puffy Chair is a low-key road movie that, fittingly enough, has knocked around the festival circuit for a while and opened in a few theaters before arriving in New York today. The journey it depicts is similarly unhurried.
Based on a novel by Armistead Maupin, which was based in turn on an episode in Mr. Maupins life, The Night Listener explores a shadowy region between truth and fiction.
As a cultural artifact, Talladega Nights is both completely phony and, therefore, utterly authentic. Or, to put it differently: this movie is the real thing.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Kirby Dick's feisty, intellectually engaging documentary tries to illuminate an aspect of moviemaking and moviegoing that is deliberately left in the dark.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Mixing pop savvy with startling formal ambition, Michael Mann transforms a long, fairly predictable cop-show episode into a dazzling (and sometimes daft) Wagnerian spectacle.
Like an electioneering candidate, Steve Zaillian's version of All the Kings Men makes a lot of promises but fails to deliver the goods.
Todd Fields' superb film adaptation of the novel by Tom Perrotta result is challenging, accessible and hard to stop thinking about.
Babel possesses unusual aesthetic force, even if it does not seem to be tethered to any coherent idea or narrative logic.
This appreciative look at the life and work of theater artist Robert Wilson includes a notably candid interview with the man himself.
The best that can be said about Gabriel Range's opportunistic fake-umentary is that it faithfully recreates the tone and rhythm of a second-rate American television program.
Entertaining, spirited and shamelessly gimmicky, Christopher Nolan's film tells the intricate tale of two rival magicians practicing their art in late-Victorian London.
The problem is that the efforts of the actors don't add up to much more than a series of uncomfortable, funny-horrible vignettes in a scattered, shapeless movie.
In 51 Birch Street, a moving and fascinating documentary, Doug Block investigates the lingering, buried frustration in his parents otherwise ordinary lives.
Michel Gondry's beguiling new film is so profoundly idiosyncratic, and so confident in its oddity, that any attempt to describe it is bound to be misleading.

Neither sensationalistic nor sentimental, Ms. Berg's film is clear-sighted, tough-minded and devastating, a portrait of individual criminality and institutional indifference, a study in the betrayal of trust and the irresponsibility of authority.
There is no reason to choose between Bennett Miller's Capote, which came out almost exactly a year ago, and Douglas McGrath's Infamous, which opens today... Both stand out above the biopic pack.
Highly theatrical and yet also intimate and informal, Marie Antoinette lets its story slink almost casually through its lovingly composed and rendered images.
In a pre-election season full of drama, contention and surprise, Man of the Year arrives on the scene with the blistering impact of a spoonful of cold mashed potatoes.
The latest chapter in Michael Apted's documentary series shows that at 49, lives reveal more about marriage and the life cycle than about class.
The Guardian is an action movie, a basic training movie, a swaggering sea adventure, a home front melodrama and an inspiring tough-love heroic teacher fable.
Dito Montiel's autobiographical tale is so full of life and feeling that the screen can hardly contain it.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This time [Gilliam] has stumbled into a different no-manâ(TM)s land, the one between the merely bad and the completely indefensible.
Mining his own chidlhood, Noah Baumbach has put together an unsparing, funny portrait of a family in crisis and a young man trying to figure out his parents and himself.
This picture achieves a level of badness that is its own form of sublimity.
Ira Sachs's beautiful, melancholy film, winner of the top prize at Sundance this year, features a passionate performance by Rip Torn as a legendary record producer.

If you like the music, you will appreciate Mr. Kell's attention to it, and relish the on-camera presence of legends like Kool Herc and Afrika Bambaataa. But '5 Sides of a Coin' will make your head nod more than it makes your eyes widen or your ears pop.
Seven years after Fuller's death, 24 years after its initial, botched release, and almost 60 years after V-E day, The Big Red One is finally here, in a form close to what Fuller intended.
A churning, affectionate group portrait, a cinematic pendant to a New Yorker piece Jay McInerney wrote about Fat Possum a few years back.
The big-screen rendition of SpongeBob SquarePants is a marvel of unleashed childishness, like a birthday party on the edge of spinning out of control.
Alain Corneau's psychodrama is the latest movie to explore (and to exploit) Western fascination with Japan.
This film of middle school students who managed to create a Holocaust memorial is so self-congratulatory it tugs against the gravity of the Holocaust itself.
Mr. Lou synthesizes a wide range of styles and influences -- from Casablanca to Wong Kar-wai -- resulting in a movie that, for all its haunting strangeness, seems curiously familiar.
In spite of the teasing promise of its title, Mike Nichols's deft drama does everything it can to push you away.
A minor example of a major genre: the feel-good Holocaust movie.
Zana Briski's documentary about children growing up in Calcutta's rough and squalid red light district is moving, charming and sad.
I should have been completely exasperated with The Life Aquatic, with its wispy story and wonder-cabinet production design, but to my surprise I found it mostly delightful.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Mr. Sawant does his best to balance hopeful sentiment with the depressing prospect of a child's world going dark, and he tries to infuse this simple melodrama with a sense of tenderness and beauty.
Clint Eastwood's drama about a grizzled boxing trainer and a spunky young fighter is the best movie released by a major Hollywood studio this year.
[Brooks] opts for soothing fakery and empty multicultural rhetoric to send us home feeling good about ourselves and partaking of the surplus smugness that he clearly has to spare.
The screen version of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical lacks both authentic romance and the thrill of memorable spectacle.
Nicole Kassell's lean, disturbing first film stars Kevin Bacon as a child molester struggling to re-enter society after 12 years in prison.
Shakespeare's most problematic play at least with respect to modern sensitivities receives an intelligent interpretation from Michael Radford and a superb cast.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Czech Republic's nominee for the best foreign film Oscar skips from buoyant satire to domestic melodrama, leaving behind a curious mix of emotions.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Bahman Ghobadi's third film presents a harsh account of war, displacement and deprivation that is saved from utter bleakness by a tough, earthy lyricism.
Keanu Reeves plays a haunted, expressionless traveler in an overblown theological thriller based on the DC/Vertigo comic book Hellblazer.
This suspenseful German drama is set during the final days of Adolph Hitler's life, when the once-fearsome Nazi military machine had all but collapsed.
Fans of action movies will find much to appreciate in this symphony of flying limbs, breaking bones and elaborately staged chases and confrontations.
Thirty-nine years after it first appeared, Jean-Luc Godard's document of youthful confusion has not aged one minute.
Though it has its share of carnality, Bill Condon's wise and witty biography of the sex researcher Alfred C. Kinsey is, above all, an intellectual turn-on.
An average romantic comedy, starring Will Smith and Eva Mendes, that is as soft and sweet as a marshmallow, and about as interesting.
A small movie about a small world, but its modesty is part of what makes it durable and satisfying.
Both sweet and stringent, attuned to the wonders of childhood as well as its cruelty and terror.
Don't avoid the new Assault on Precinct 13 because it's a remake. There are plenty of other reasons.
Has a plot that frolics in the no-man's land between fiendish complexity and utter incomprehensibility.
Samuel L. Jackson plays the real-life coach of a high school basketball team in this solid, unsurprising sports drama.
This German documentary gathers some of the products of the German culture industry from the 1930's and 40's into a monstrous and fascinating collage.
A harrowing, tender film.
This documentary tells the story of Troy Duffy, a bartender in Los Angeles who became a minor celebrity when Miramax offered him $1 million for a screenplay.
Pixar's new animated action-comedy, about a superhero family stuck in middle-class suburban exile, comes tantalizingly close to greatness.

Without Ms. Kidman's brilliantly nuanced performance, Birth might feel arch, chilly and a little sadistic, but she gives herself so completely to the role that the film becomes both spellbinding and heartbreaking.
It has a familiar, lived-in feel, and if its observations of rural life at a time of political turmoil don't feel terribly original, they are nonetheless absorbing and sometimes powerful.
Every time Mr. Sayles faces a choice between high-minded didacticism and persuasive drama, you can almost hear him tapping the lectern for your full attention.

It's an honest, unpretentious, well-made B picture with a clever, silly premise, a handful of sly, unassuming performances and enough car chases, decent jokes and swervy plot complications to make the price of the ticket seem like a decent bargain.
Christoffer Boe's self-assured first feature is a moody, enigmatic love story set in the cool elegance of Copenhagen's classical squares and modernist hotels.
[T]his [...] film by Randolph Kret mistakes the study of a particularly virulent set of symptoms for a diagnosis... Nuance is not something Mr. Kret has much use for.
Stephen Fry's adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's Vile Bodies honors its source with vigor and gusto, capturing both Waugh's cheeky humor and his dark, stringent moralism.
John Waters's first film in four years is a grindingly anarchic attempt to have it both ways, to be both cheerfully inclusive and in-your-face nasty.
Jacob Aaron Estes's debut film, about an adolescent prank gone wrong, is like an unusually sensitive and well-acted afterschool special.
The murk and mystery of marriage, adultery and friendship have seldom been illuminated with such harsh precision.
Michael Winterbottom's somber dystopian romance is thick with disquieting, not always coherent ideas about the effects of globalization on human intimacy.
This minimalist thriller evokes some deep and primal fears, but it is ultimately too under-dramatized to provoke anything more intense than squirming discomfort.

For Mr. Miike's fans, it will be an indispensable compendium of outtakes and sketches. For others, it will be a mystifying and provocative introduction to his unnerving, wanton and prodigious imagination.
Jonathan Demme, updating John Frankenheimer's classic exercise in cold war liberal paranoia, has made a witty, anxious thriller for a new age of political uncertainty.
The Wayward Cloud offers one plausible moral: If life hands you watermelons, make love to them.
This grisly, comical shaggy-dog thriller from Mexico provides the latest evidence that the international movement we might call Tarantinismo is alive and well.
It's not bad enough to make you curse, but you are likely to laugh when you should scream, and to roll your eyes when you are meant to laugh.
Walter Salles's stirring and warm-hearted film reconstructs a journey across South America taken by Ernesto Guevara before his career as a revolutionary.
Swimming in the lucrative wake of Finding Nemo, DreamWorks's foray into computer-generated underwater animation is a rambunctious, reasonably amusing pop confection.
Taylor Hackford's biography of Ray Charles is a potent and invigorating portrait of genius, thanks to Jamie Foxx's performance and to the music of Ray Charles himself.
Rather than delve into the clinical details of sexual desire and behavior, Catherine Breillat's reflects on what it means for a filmmaker to conduct such an inquiry.
Lucrecia Martel's elusive, feverish and altogether amazing second feature seems to communicate as much to the nerves and skin as to the eyes and ears.
The real problem, it seems to me, is not that Mr. Solondz goes too far, but that he seems to have no particular direction in mind, no artistic interest beyond the limitless ugliness of humanity.
To skip Ousmane Sembene's Moolaade would be to miss an opportunity to experience the embracing, affirming, world-changing potential of humanist cinema at its finest.
Playing a star of the prewar London theater uneasily stepping into middle age, Annette Bening manages a hectic plot with glamour and aplomb.
The premise of this Disney-funded movie, based on a true story, is promising, but the film itself is a hard slog.
More satisfying as a straight-ahead blow 'em up than as a satire.
An ingenious first film made on a budget of about $7,000 by a former engineer and self-taught filmmaker about the perils of ingenuity.
A 17th century Star is Born, though with interestingly convoluted sexual politics and a provocative historical thesis.
Peter Berg directs this Texas high school football extravaganza in a tough, gritty style that gives it an unusually fine and vivid sense of place.
Certainly one of the strangest and most interesting movies of the year, and I suspect that in years to come a number of other strange and interesting movies will show traces of its influence.
George Butler's new documentary, unabashed in its admiration for John Kerry, is clearly meant to intervene in the current presidential campaign.
movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A witty and acute examination of friendship, ambition and betrayal in the Parisian literary world.
Though it is in constant, breathtaking motion, Zhang Yimou's gorgeous entertainment is not especially moving.
Predictable though it is, the picture is rousing and well paced, and the final competition is effectively suspenseful.
A slight, amusing documentary.
Make no mistake, this movie is terribly silly, but it's not completely terrible.
The stories and personalities that do emerge are touching and intriguing.
Yes offers a case study in the moral complacency of the creative class, and its verbal cleverness cannot disguise the vacuous self-affirmation summed up in the title.
The director has an intuitive, buoyant sympathy for young people.
Steven Spielberg's reasonably entertaining rendering of the 1898 H. G. Wells novel is an elemental story of predator and prey.
Compared with the psychological probing and spiritual brooding of Batman Begins, Fantastic Four is proudly dumb, loud and inconsequential.
It is hard not to admire the independence and ambition of The Beautiful Country, even if the film does fall short of its epic intentions.
Wondrous and flawed.
Craig Brewer's first feature film is a volatile mixture of slickness and sincerity, hard-edged naturalism and sheer show-business hokum.
This lavish, exhaustingly kinetic film is smarter than you might expect, and at the same time dumber than it could be.
Three young Berliners frustrated at the iniquities of global capitalism cross the line that separates provocation and protest from serious crime.
An essay film, a work of painstaking and penetrating scholarship, and, as such, one of the most original and rigorous pieces of criticism in any medium I have encountered in quite some time.
Dai Sijie's tender, touching adaptation of his own novel of the same title.
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Hubert Sauper's harrowing, indispensable documentary about Tanzania presents the agonized human face of globalization.
The Dukes of Hazzard is the latest evidence that, for Hollywood studios at least, there can never be too much of a mediocre thing.
With Broken Flowers, Jim Jarmusch's sly, touching new film, Bill Murray reaffirms his status as the quietest comic actor in movies today.
Fernando Meirelles's excellent adaptation of the novel by John le Carré is likely to linger in your mind and may even trouble your conscience.
This graceful and sympathetic look at how the lives of teenagers intersect with a work of literature won several César awards in France.
Bennett Miller's film is a fascinating and fine-grained reconstruction of the period in which Truman Capote wrote In Cold Blood.
Thomas Vinterberg and Lars von Trier take another step toward intellectual bankruptcy with a pretentious film about a group of pacifists obsessed with handguns.
With tact and enthusiasm, Roman Polanski grabs hold of a great book and rediscovers its true and enduring vitality.
George Clooney's film about the CBS newsman Edward R. Murrow is a passionate, thoughtful essay on power, truth-telling and responsibility.
[Ferraz] digs into the past to illuminate Kalatozov's extraordinary blend of formal bravura and revolutionary didacticism.
movie_title: I am Cuba, the Siberian Mammoth (Soy Cuba, O Mamute Siberiano) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Mike Mills's feature-film debut manages to show how calamitous and out of control (and also how thrilling) growing up odd and ordinary can be.
Pawel Pawlikowski's lovely film tells a modest story. But it is a triumph of mood and implication.
The adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foer's best-selling novel is whimsical when it should be darkly funny and poignant when it should be devastating.
Michael Murphy's documentary about the musical traditions of New Orleans can serve as an apt, wrenching elegy for the city's unique contribution to American culture.
The idea that anyone would mistake Eugene Levy for Samuel L. Jackson is just about the funniest thing in this action-buddy comedy.
While not especially good, The Exorcism of Emily Rose, directed by Scott Derrickson, is still a fascinating cultural document in the age of intelligent design.
Alex Shuper's wonderfully informative (if oddly titled) documentary examines editing, a central component of cinema that is often neglected or taken for granted.
movie_title: Edge Codes: The Art of Motion Picture Editing (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A sometimes enthralling, sometimes exhausting tour de force.
The latest bit of damaged goods offered up in the Miramax clearance sale, Underclassman plays like the longest episode of 21 Jump Street ever made.
Given its somewhat morbid premise, this metaphysical second-chance comedy is impressively nimble and cheery.
While Miranda July's first feature film might be classified as romantic comedy, it introduces the playful qualities of installation art to the conventions of narrative cinema.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Park Chan-Wook's Joint Security Area is a fairly straightforward whodunit with a pointedly political theme and an unapologetically humanist message.
movie_title: JSA: Joint Security Area (Gongdong gyeongbi guyeok JSA) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: François Ozon uses reverse chronology to tell the story of a failed marriage. The device is not exactly a novelty, but it does make some dramatic sense in this case.
This sober, informative chronicle of the biggest business scandal of the decade is almost indecently entertaining.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: While this documentary about a religious pilgrimage in India feels haphazard and superficial, the glimpses it offers are never less than fascinating.
movie_title: Short Cut to Nirvana: Kumbh Mela (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The reasons to avoid House of D, David Duchovny's earnest, unwatchable coming-of-age drama, can best be summarized in a simple declarative sentence. Robin Williams plays a retarded janitor.
This brutal chronicle of heavily armed drug dealers is best appreciated (or disdained) as a raw, bracing expression of the spirit of capitalism.
Stephen Chow's kinetic, exhausting, relentlessly entertaining film throws scraps of a half-century of international pop culture into a fast-whirling blender.
Like many modern allegories, Nimrod Antal's tour de force of grime, fluorescence and destinationless velocity is more concerned with atmosphere than meaning.
Mr. Zee's attempt to marry American-style realism with the big, artificial emotions of Indian and Pakistani popular film does not quite work, in spite of the evident love he brings to the project.
Beauty Shop extends the popular Barbershop franchise to Atlanta and provides a sassy feminine counterpart to its cozy men's-club vibe.
Jonathan Nossiter, in his documentary, is more interested in the sobering facts of global marketing, economic competition and cultural imperialism than in wine as a beverage.

Melinda and Melinda is perhaps best thought of as an offering to the memories of Ernst Lubitsch and George S. Kaufman, half-forgotten culture heroes whose examples of crisp sophistication deserve to be kept alive for future generations.
A coming-of-age story that is sensitive and well observed -- if also somewhat conventional.
What could have been a provocative psychological drama is instead a dishonestly romantic exploration of narcissism and exploitation.
A reminder that when it comes to innovative animated entertainment for all ages, there is Pixar, there is Japan and there is everybody else.
The upside of Mike Binder's deeply flawed attempt to marry midlife romantic comedy with domestic farce is two nearly perfect performances by Joan Allen and Kevin Costner.
This loose, pointless remake of Guess Who's Coming to Dinner at least suggests that American racial attitudes have relaxed since 1967.
A welcome antidote to the self-convinced rhetoric of pundits and politicians.
Conventionally described as a political thriller, but The Interpreter is as apolitical as it is unthrilling.

A small, plain movie, shot in 16 millimeter in dull locations around Boston; but also, like its passive, quizzical heroine, it is unexpectedly seductive, and even, in its own stubborn, hesitant way, beautiful.
Superfluous though it may be, The Honeymooners is not so bad.
The latest animated tour de force from the Japanese director Hayao Miyazak is a fitting introduction to one of modern cinema's great enchanters.
Lords of Dogtown, from start to finish, is pretty much a blast.
Werner Herzog's documentary suggests that while the German filmmaker has mellowed a bit with age, he is still fascinated by the danger and romance of the natural world.
In Volker Schlöndorff's somber moral thriller, a Roman Catholic priest, temporarily released from Dachau, finds his conscience tested when the Nazis try to co-opt him.
Like many computer-animated features, this one, about four animals exiled from the Central Park Zoo, expends most of its imaginative resources on clever visuals.
Kim Ki-duk's touching and improbable love story is pleasingly mysterious without being too difficult and a little gimmicky but not annoyingly so.
This is by far the best film in the more recent trilogy, and also the best of the four episodes Mr. Lucas has directed. That's right: it's better than Star Wars.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A so-so family sports comedy that aims a weak satirical kick at the divided soul of the American middle-class dad, as personified by Will Ferrell.
New York City fifth graders determinedly go through the paces of traditional ballroom dancing in this slight, charming documentary.
One of the best detective thrillers ever filmed.
Mysterious Skin is infused with remarkable tenderness and beauty.
The set design is fairly elaborate by the standards of the genre, and the victims don't die in precisely the order you might expect, but everything else goes pretty much according to formula.

So much feeling, so much skill, so much seriousness, such an urgent moral agenda -- all of this must surely answer our collective hunger for a good movie, or even a great one, about race and class in a modern American city. Not even close.
A fascinating curiosity, a chance to witness one major filmmaker paying tribute to another in the form of a rigorously minor film.
Through the murk and gloom of The Abandoned; a mystery emerges: Why didn't this go straight to DVD?
In keeping with the grandeur of its title, The Human Condition is anything but modest in scope and ambition.
movie_title: Ningen no joken I (The Human Condition I) (No Greater Love) (1959)

movie_review_blurb: In spite of Amelia Vincent's toothsome cinematography and the down-home locations, the movie often has the lumbering, literal-minded rhythms of a second-rate stage play -- not a moan or a howl, but a slow, anxious groan.
Packages a real-life story of athletic triumph and social progress into an accessible, rousing melodrama that is no less potent for being almost entirely predictable.
Max Payne is content to be an efficient vehicle for the delivery of a familiar range of sensations, some of which almost rise to the level of feelings.
The Secret Life of Bees insists so strenuously on its themes of redemption, tolerance, love and healing that it winds up defeating itself.
The title of Barry Levinson's new movie, What Just Happened, is not phrased as a question, but if it were it would demand another question in response: 'Who cares?'
In the drama I've Loved You So Long, Kristin Scott Thomas's furious honesty rules out easy, unearned redemption.
Pride and Glory, directed by Gavin O'Connor, plods across familiar ground. It's yet another movie about the fraternal disorder of the police.
Moments of obviousness are offset by a feeling of gritty lyricism in Wayne Wang's "Princess of Nebraska," a beautifully shot but awkwardly acted movie that is available only online.
When it works best, Changeling is a feverish and bluntly effective parable of wronged innocence.
A new documentary offers a salutary and touching reminder that the race, like nearly everything else great about New York City, was the creation of a stubborn visionary.
Zack and Miri Make a Porno, in spite of its lewdness, follows a gee-whiz romantic-comedy formula that would not be out of place on the Disney Channel.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With Splinter, the director Toby Wilkins honors the conventions of the horror genre with skill and enough wit to keep the scares sharp.
One Day You'll Understand contains no great revelations or surprises, but rather is suffused with a quiet glow of sympathy and enlightenment.
The phrase 'divorced couple' sounds like an oxymoron, but there's really no other way to describe the Dutch ex-spouses whose table talk dominates Stages.
Soul Men is a raucous, rambling comedy, offering some laughs, some groans and a feast for fans of the musical idioms it mocks and celebrates.
This may well be the most memorable Jean-Claude Van Damme movie ever, but I'm afraid that's not saying much.
Quantum of Solace prompts the question: Is revenge the only possible motive for large-scale movie heroism these days?
After two and a half hours in the thrilling, exhausting company of the characters in A Christmas Tale, the intimacy we feel with them is wired with surprise.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonist's condition.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The richness of The Secret of the Grain lies in the close, tireless, enthusiastic attention it pays to the most mundane daily tasks.
movie_title: La Graine et le Mulet (The Secret of the Grain) (Couscous) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I would tell you to go out and see it for yourself, but you might take that as a recommendation rather than a plea for corroboration. Did I really see what I thought I saw?
