Global politics, if not pronounced in the story, are still in the air. This makes Being 17 the most perceptive movie I've yet seen to deal with Europe's contemporary turmoil as evident in its characters' moral lives.
The Girl on the Train...is so thoroughly lousy that it augurs a horrible future for the American movie-going plebiscite.

Malick the animist moves into abstraction, like Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey F/X, but he ends with amazement, like Godard's late spiritual films. And this isn't just IMAX novelty...Malick brings cinema back to its phenomenological beginning.
movie_title: Voyage of Time: The IMAX Experience (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The 13th is full of accusations by opportunists-posing-as-historians who profit from reinforcing the fear that black Americans by and large have not experienced progress.
American Honey...struck me as unbearably phony...Each scene is a provocation and an indictment, but the film's also an offense to the principles of cinéma vérité and social realism.
Masterminds, directed by Jared Hess, needs to go deeper into the tension between the way pop culture betrays its audience by displacing personal needs and then indoctrinating greed and restlessness.

Queen of Katwe may suggest the title of a Disney animated princess (like the lamentable The Princess and the Frog), but all possibilities of romantic fantasy are submerged in the film's semi-documentary reporting on eternal Third World poverty.

This unoriginal reboot reveals Washington and Fuqua to be hacks as they take on a formerly great genre, the Western...This craven, doubled-down remake reduces America's difficult history to a series of violent, affectless, and inept set-pieces.

Stone forgets he's telling a story of sedition, and he loses both his sense of human nature and his cinematic dazzle...Stone abets these traitors' pride. His skill as a filmmaker and his virtue as a disgruntled American are the immediate casualties.

This documentary itself is a whirlwind of deceit, switching tenses at will, as if to legitimize Albert's particular delusions, still enjoying her game and the cultural myths to which liberals are susceptible.

Instead of mending fences in Sully, Eastwood works through both awe and disbelief, recognizing underappreciated professionalism...by looking back at "the miracle on the Hudson" with a sobering, unsentimental sense of recent history.

This hagiographic film is like one of those TV magazine shows about the upper classes: It revives radical chic for Millennial viewers, shows off Berger and Swinton's style, taste, and progressive political options.
movie_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In this doc, Hunter earns awareness and compassion for his gay life story. Today's Hollywood has no equivalent movie star.

Lo and Behold: Reveries of the Connected World is an alarum about the Internet, a prophecy about man's self-annihilating instincts as shown through interviews with awed scientists and skeptical victims of technology.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Tanne's on-screen myth-making is a bland cocktail of race, class, and super-chaste sexuality, going so far past Authorized Flattery that it resembles a hustle.

The most deeply felt part of A Taste of Honey is its love story between soul mates - white, black, female, male, straight, and gay...Melvin's Geoff is an achingly believable character, heroic for his time - and ours, too. We owe a debt of gratitude.
David Mackenzie's Hell or High Water further challenges Hollywood's unethical trends. It twists the outlawry of two white Texas brothers...into a study of millennial cynicism.

Its story of a despot (Mikheil Gomiashvili)...who escapes his country's...capital city...with his cosseted grandson (Dachi Orvelashvili) in tow...looks at brotherhood by satirizing the highhanded excesses of nationhood.
Jarman's goal was reportorial-to investigate, witness and reveal an aspect of gay nightlife-but he captured a fleeting yet timeless and fundamental essence of the culture.
Contemporary Color verges on cultural satire minus cynicism...This is bread and circuses for hipsters.
Lady Bird is a sensible tribute to the spirit of Claudia Alta Taylor Johnson. . .The film's conflicts are surprisingly touching.

LBJ isn't a satire like Oliver Stone's serious lampoon of a political scion. It's something less - and weirder. . .This third-rate but expedient film regrets the decency we've lost and that Reiner is nostalgic for.
Novitiate is a scandalous, shameless anti-Catholic freak show.
BPM is a near-great film about hope and suffering that gives sex its proper rank in the scale of human relations.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Square is probably the film of the year - though that's not necessarily a good thing.
[U]nbearable to watch. . .There is no plot here, to speak of, just an indulgent display of each male's obnoxious behavior, separated into pseudo-literary chapters.
Against the tide of political correctness, The Delta was first to chart the unsafe streams of gay experience.
Nobody's Watching vacillates between being an immigration sob story or a treatise on gay freedom.
Yet. seeing Laakonsens' fantasies realized exponentially confirms that his erotica is timeless. Tom of Finland commemorates gay culture's Toulouse-Lautrec.
Finally, a movie that sets Brokeback Mountain straight.
The raspy passion of Chavela's singing connects the romantic fatalism of Mexican folk and pop music to the soulful understanding of gay life that defines filmmakers such as [Pedro] Almodovar.
Polina [is] one of the most emotionally accurate coming-of-age films of recent years.

[T]he film treats historical matters flippantly. . .This approach would be dismissable except that it's also part of the currently fashionable ahistorical attitude toward black Americans' personal and public progress.
The Florida Project represents a new low in class condescension. . .[Director] Baker loves irresponsible, antisocial types, and his method is similarly undisciplined.
[Director] Villeneuve never strikes the moral terror that has distinguished his best films. . .Blade Runner's awesomeness is gone.
Mark Felt (subtitled "The Man Who Brought Down the White House") is a partisan fever dream that reflects the revenge fantasies of certain journalists as well as politicians and deep-state officials.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Its colorful style recalls the flamboyant amorality of GoodFellas and Blow, and it's often funnier and more succinct than either.
Unfortunately, Gyllenhaal plays the lead with one-note, ghoulish, internalized trauma, so Stronger lacks the powerful personal and cultural insight about American vulnerability.
Special emphasis is put on Abdul's religious identity; he's a Muslim begging acceptance by the West. This over-obvious metaphor ruins the film's momentarily fable-like vision.

This overlong, half-comic rewriting of the history of the 1973 tennis stunt. . .is so heavily slanted toward the goal of advancing feminism that it neglects to offer a humanely balanced portrait of the players.
This skin-deep look at young male sexuality makes Frankie's behavior perplexing.

McDonagh uses advertising as a metaphor for aggravated communication, as apparent in our media and social relations, but, regrettably, it's also a foreigner's careless simplification of America's current unease.

[The film's] message, a condensation of post-election, globalist cynicism, comes across loud and clear in Branagh's showboating direction (pointless, zooming imagery shot in 65mm) and his dull show-offing in the role of Belgian detective Hercule Poirot.
Justice League. . . [is] one of those wondrous Zack Snyder extravaganzas that fulfill the aesthetic potential of comic-book graphics and achieves essential cinema kinetics.
The Smiths aim for bigger box-office numbers by offering a secondhand fantasy that replaces academic hard work with the superficial amusement of martial arts self-defense.

Black Panther turns racial politics into what Malcolm X called "politricks" . . . The media's enthusiasm for this bland action flick is maddening. The problem isn't one particular movie, but the celebration of the illusion of "progress."
The 15:17 to Paris [is] more than the typical docu-drama and confirms director Clint Eastwood's canny political instinct and his artistic daring.
The new western Hostiles was crowded out of the Oscar circle, yet it typifies the hostility that has befallen American genre films.
Rather than simply celebrate queer highlife, this abstract view (coordinating the blue sky, sea, tanned bodies and aerial perspectives) dares us to reflect and intellectualize.
... the personal stories of individual dancers-all cute, compelling-traps the film between trendy identity politics and giving queer cultural innovation the honor it deserves.
Much more than just a mystery movie, these male-female conflicts make Mike's Murder an all-American sexual thriller.
Darkest Hour initiates a genuine, modern approach to political heroism and the Western sagacity that is out of favor. . .[It] is not jingoism; it is a politically aware, reflective performance.
Screenwriter Bill Condon. . .turns the showman's innovations in advertising and public manipulation into models of humanitarianism. This is showbiz demagoguery.
Molly's Game is a movie for those suckers who really do believe we are experiencing "the golden age of television."

[Downsizing is director Alexander] Payne's ultimate revenge on American film tradition. His inability to imagine an original story - to move an audience's basic aspirations without guilt - is another sign of decadence.

Phantom Thread is a revisionist genre film. Set in the 1950s, it not only reworks fashion flicks from Lucy Gallant to Funny Face (the complementary confluence of two industries) but perverts their female-objectifying iconography.
The Post is a snootily white-collar movie faking common-man virtues. . .[it] validates the slippery slope that brought us to today's shameless media partisanship.
This mash-up of alien and immigrant hardship, in which lonely Elisa finds sexual release with a sea creature, is pervy, ridiculous, and humorless.

The new, machine-tooled The Last Jedi is sufficiently busy (action scenes occurring every ten minutes) to make you grateful that it is, at least, agreeably paced, even if it isn't really about anything.

A satirical look at bad filmmaking that is itself bad filmmaking. . .Wiseau and Sestero are both pitied and ridiculed. . .The Disaster Artist is being bizarrely acclaimed, proof that the idea of art has died in Hollywood.
There hasn't been a piece of warped Americana this ugly since the 2003 documentary Capturing the Friedmans. Harding's humanity means less to the filmmakers than does the possibility of her guilt.
This film is strangely celibate, a tribute that stays out of the way of Morrissey's own charisma and self-mythologizing.
Every risible moment exposes the filmmaker's class, race and gender contempt-it's camp on ice and the farthest thing from the gay sensibility that contemporary Hollywood sorely lacks.
Compared with. . .any number of films dealing with down-to-earth sexual feelings that go wild. . .Call Me By Your Name is trite. . .Few recent films have so bluntly proclaimed moral pessimism.

Mudbound typifies a new kind of unpleasant entertainment based on social-justice homilies. . .But Mudbound becomes tiresome from its opening scene. . .[It] lacks the authenticity and justification of genuine folk art.
Brad's Status. . .is a drama only because it is humorless. The story. . .becomes maudlin and self-pitying.

Aronofsky's mania for various tribulations never finds a higher meaning, and his emphasis on female discomfort (Lawrence looks zombified, both clueless and hypersensitive) makes him the perfect filmmaker for the Hillary Clinton era.
Spettacolo is a cultural rumination more than a documentary... It's a grassroots illustration of the instinct to preserve cultural tradition.
It only seems like "fun" if you fall for King's obvious, contemptuous treatment of American innocence.
Wonder Woman downplays Diana's pursuit of destiny in the fight against evil...Diana, like her introductory movie, has childlike enthusiasm but no passion.
The combination of over-the-top action-movie stunts and crass humor is shameless, both below-the-belt and beneath most folks' IQs.
Ridley Scott has ruined the Alien franchise...So far, Alien: Covenant is the year's most obscene Hollywood undertaking.
Only Hawn and director Jonathan Levine impart a humane context...Schumer has created a grating persona that lacks decency, trust, and charm.
Modern politics - as well as essential, unchanging human personality - come into play in Ritchie's historical, action-adventure extravaganza.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Class privilege is the real subject of Paris Can Wait...Lane's best film performance ever features a woman's subtle knowingness about fending off amatory male aggression.
The Circle's thriller plot becomes clumsy and banal, and loses its potential ideological critique...the filmmakers fall short of satire that is also meaningful political critique.
[A] fascinating and exasperating film ...
A surprisingly imaginative animated movie.
An early candidate for worst film of the year: Nacho Vigalondo's Colossal. This feminist sci-fi is a tribute to misandry.

Instead of giving Millennials the heroic gender transition that they demand, Hill insists that we think deeper - perhaps about the media's popularizing of sex reassignment and the painful complications that such a choice entails.
Mungiu's moralism is like that in Death of a Salesman: It rationalizes and sentimentalizes common corruption.
Its lack of wonderment - also absent political confession such as Rudyard Kipling's concept of the white man's burden - typifies our obtuse contemporary movie culture.
I'm predisposed to like this exposé, especially given the American media class's unfeeling arrogance and lack of self-awareness and scruple. But Julia and Kiril's insensitivity is too familiar.

Dickinson's isolated intelligence and artistry are subjects unique to Davies's filmmaking. A kind of creative fury - apparent in Davies's radical formalism (and made vivid by actress Cynthia Nixon) - is what drives this movie.
Akron is a nice try at normalizing gay romance, but the filmmaking needs the erotic and spiritual masculine energy of great gay cinema.
Through the story of Adrian and Anna's grief and shared passion, Ozon discovers means to greater, more universal, gay empathy.
CHiPs...reflects the general mindlessness of mainstream entertainment.
The major quest in Song to Song is Malick's search for a story. He may be one of the last Hollywood believers, but this time his filmmaking amounts to nothingness.

The speciously "evolved" sexual and social attitudes of this updated fairy tale flatten and coarsen the Beauty and the Beast myth...The Disney approach is childish, and it is not justified by political trendiness...
My Life as a Zucchini...is nearly perfect, perhaps the best animated film in years.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Cruise's The Mummy merely updates the horror genre to fit a meaningless, diversionary paradigm...[It] does little more than reflect dark, Millennial political unease.
Designed, like all movie franchises, to fulfill the Millennial urge for escapist entertainment, Kong: Skull Island is the blockbuster as junky postmodern bread and circuses.
[A] bleeding-hearts' melodrama...Beatriz at Dinner shows the secret wish of liberals who both fear and despise their social inferiors.

[Maudie] details the real-life perseverance of Nova Scotia-based folk artist Maud Lewis (1903-1970) who, despite crippling rheumatoid arthritis, flourished as a primitive painter...Hawkins's and Hawke's performances are the year's best so far.
The Teacher dramatizes fascist fascination and the banal resistance.
The juvenile comedy, starring Ice Cube and Charlie Day as high-school teachers set to rumble at day's end, weakly satirizes our immature, primitive urges.
Crown Heights needs more such insight. Instead, its docu-fantasy style often rings as clichéd.

4 Days in France not only maps national consensus, but as it explores different characters (from a lonely, risky 20-year-old to a middle-aged veteran libertine), it also charts an alternative history of French philosophy.
[Patti Cake$] is one of the few American movies specifically about class issues, but it also confuses them.
The cinematic abomination Good Time is...an unapologetic docu-comedy of low-life, cultural autism...instead of a genre parody, it is hipster neo-realism.
Once again, Hollywood uses history to show off liberal sanctimony, this time through a story set during Detroit's 1967 race riots.
In Desert Hearts, [Donna] Deitch takes lesbian cinema back to its future.

American gay movies never contemplate gay life as having existential or spiritual meaning but that is [Joao Pedro] Rodrigues' adventure in this strange, mesmerizing study of the transformation of gay consciousness.
Using music to define gay experience in a prep school setting makes Handsome Devil a queer version of Wes Anderson's Rushmore.

Cotillard's madwoman contortions cannot pass for innocent adolescent pique, and this exposes the film's fakery...with sidelong references to imperialism and immigration, the film becomes increasingly absurd and indulgent.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Atomic Blonde is junk.
Imagine Star Wars, Lord of the Rings, The Matrix, etc. rolled up in one but corralled by a good director with impish humor.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [N]early two hours of uninspiring mayhem...Dunkirk uses history as a pretext to show off the director's fascination for calamity.

Bondy's gimmicky film isn't as beautifully tricky as Clare Peploe's Marivaux adaptation, The Triumph of Love (2001), but through Huppert and Fitzgerald's artistry, he personalizes Western tradition sweetly.

Bronx Gothic...follows the usual pattern of Hollywood's imprisoning blacks within the limits of white liberal imagination...Rossi's liberalism - his whitesplaining - intrudes on his star's storytelling.
Girls Trip's black female quartet confirms the all-American commitment to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.
With its brief allusion to that iconic, indefatigable cartoon sailor, Pop Aye is a children's movie for childish adults. No amount of outsider cuteness makes up for Tan's dry storytelling.
Bong wants us to get worked up ...but Okja's plot itself is modified for people who don't know they're watching propaganda so long as it pushes their buttons and makes them feel virtuous.
Once again, the Transformer series verges on absurdity but that's less important than the unique big-screen spectacle of Bay's pop-art and futurist filmmaking.
[T]his adaptation of Don Siegel's 1971 drama...becomes another of Sofia Coppola's listless spoiled-girl forays.
This nightmarish spectacle boasts about its principles...Trevorrow, Hurwitz, and Focus Features serve up this sadistic pabulum as if they were seriously addressing human issues.

As Jia guides Salles through Fenyang, formerly a prison, and his past shooting locations, and as he introduces old friends and neighbors, the documentary gives evidence of how a director translates personal experience and political perspective into film.
movie_title: Jia Zhangke, a Guy from Fenyang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This film's generational awareness is a welcome change from the mainstream media's usual treatment of LGBTQ issues as different than other, traditional sexual concerns.

Beneath the impertinent, literary banter is a sedate - almost cold - vision of cruelty, greed, and selfishness. It recalls Stillman's The Last Days of Disco (1998), but without the soulful warmth of disco music to buoy the characters' urbane desperation.
Denis' elliptical narrative avoids politics. This siege tale ignores the details of colonial life to gloss its chaotic collapse. Her equanimity is tiresome.

Cole's appreciation for how women cope and achieve goes in the right direction, more so than the pathetic sob stories by which Tyler Perry, Oprah Winfrey and Lee Daniels have stereotyped African- American female experience.
Denzel and Tony have made their least offensive, easiest-on-the-mind, most enjoyable movie.
Morning Glory is just routine Hollywood dishonesty (with the most annoying song-score since Juno) and wastes its stars.
It is Dunham's disregard of privilege, her indifference to social climbing, that provides Tiny Furniture's disarmingly modest personal vision.
Even in the same year as Raging Bull, Melvin and Howard, Dressed to Kill and The Long Riders it was still the freshest, most thrilling movie to behold.
movie_title: Every Man for Himself (Sauve qui peut (la vie)) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Perry's weakness for the lowest common denominator transforms both anger and affirmation into sludge, not great poetic cinema like Spielberg's The Color Purple, Jonathan Demme's Beloved or Rodrigo Garcia's Mother and Child.
It takes a sitcom approach to male class differences and flatters the juvenile behavior that's become the favorite, indulged subject of comedians and TV writers.
This insufferable mixture of partisan principle and exploitation-movie gimcrack is part of the contemporary political and cultural carelessness now rampant in movies, TV, the press and the Internet.
Each scene in The King's Speech is so poorly staged that its ineptitude sometimes borders on the avant-garde.
Aestheticizing Ralston's calamity animates Boyle's facile themes of modernity vs. nature, body vs. mind.
Strange Powers should be a cautionary cultural prognosis. Instead, it's a promotional film.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Chabrol re-imagines the detective genre in the course of practicing it.

Steve O's Super Cocktail Bungee routine in a feces-filled port-a-john utilizes distance and trajectory in a way that recalls the great waterslide joke in Norbit (and should help rehabilitate that wonderful film's unfair reputation).

Hereafter is really full of half-thoughts. As with Woody Allen's You Will Meet a Tall, Dark Stranger, it's difficult to tell if this film confronts belief or if disbelief simply is being given the upper hand.

Carlos gives hipsters Munich minus the moral conviction and dramatic cogency that hipsters fashionably distrust. It's being presented in two versions: 330 minutes and 165 minutes, one as emotionally flat as the other.
With entertaining clarity, writer-director Charles Ferguson explains what caused the recession that began September 15, 2008.

Unafraid of her subject's complexity, von Trotta shows Bingen's weaknesses as part of her humanity, as in her attachment to novice Richardis von Stade, who rouses the other, narcissistic side of Bingen's will.
movie_title: Vision: From the Life of Hildegard von Bingen (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Berlanti's irreality -- following the cutesy script by Ian Deitchman and Kristin Rusk Robinson -- results in a synthetic vision of life that is, essentially, an appeasement of the pre-fab, bourgeois status quo.
Nowhere Boy makes Lennon's rocky personal journey parallel the cultural upheaval of rock 'n' roll -- a revolution that changed social custom, family life and private instinct.
Downplaying Doctorow's condescending literary and class ironies, Ireland creates something more like a queer-inflected Candide.
Showcasing Aguilera's attempt to sound like a 50-year-old black woman in the guise of white appropriation, Burlesque sells a myth about show business that is both unwelcome and shopworn.
Zwick's bizarre concoction fakes insight about sex, biology and social criticism about medicine and business, yet it's really aggressively sentimental on every level.

By mixing up and confusing the purpose of cinematic amusement and fairy tales, Tangled is aptly named for the mass misperception of popular entertainment as a mechanism of gimmicks rather than an expression of feelings.
Willis' careful balancing act between portraying a unique family unit and the peculiarities of genius winds up making The Woodmans disturbing in an unexpected way.
It lugs around old moral baggage but misses a profound confrontation with the specter of Jewish guilt.
Rogen's image and his attitude as co-screenwriter of The Green Hornet updates the bland superhero template using comic irreverence.
Admittedly, Cox's humor is eccentric, but I like it.
Gwyneth Paltrow must be a great actress because, as country singer Kelly Canter in Country Strong, she seems totally unaware of her insurmountable blandness.

Despite Blue Valentine's blatant sensememories of nakedness and affection, irritation and itch, what Gosling and Williams reveal about their own concepts of heterosexual experience is ultimately inane.
Its ... characters ... have a familiarity with each other that turns everyday relations -- whether on the job, when traveling or at meals -- into startling, vivid and intimate exchanges.
A friend misread the ad for Biutiful as "Pitiful." He wasn't wrong.
A return to the possibilities of animation as Fantasia, with its multiple tones, varied episodes and restless invention, timelessly realized.
Hadewijch goes from austere images of a wintry world to remarkably beautiful images of post-rainfall lushness. From desolation to revelation, humanism becomes visible in every living thing.

True Grit speaks to our current moment of vengeful, moral uncertainty. It continues the same revamped Americana that distinguished the Coens' sophisticated remake of The Ladykillers -- a truly original religiouspolitical hybrid.
A pretext to continue one of the lamest franchises in contemporary Hollywood history.
No better than a mirthless Hollywood hack, Coppola sentimentalizes her family dilemma in order to pose as an artiste. Her navel-gazings are a boutique indie franchise.

Spacey seems to think he's making a comedy -- a good actorly instinct -- but director George Hickenlooper makes the offensive decision to treat Abramoff's transgressions as more grist for the Bush-grinding mill.
How Do You Know forges a difficult exploration of its characters' weaknesses and uncertainties. But its deepening drama becomes wishy-washy.
Rabbit Hole is a laudable art project, not great but good enough to rate comparison with stronger movies that contextualize the grief of loss and disorientation.
Everything that makes Shakespeare's final play a great expression of the dangers and risks of ambition in Western civilization is lost in this sex change.
Americans used to seeing trickedup versions of themselves in the movies (or degraded-by-narcissism versions on reality TV) will be startled at the honesty of David O. Russell's The Fighter.
Critics who praise this politically false economic fairytale can only be part of the system -- and part of the problem.
Aronofsky's ethnic denial and escape into Nina's psychological trauma actually trivializes her artistic pursuit. Turning art into genre movie silliness is a careerist's dance.
I Love You Phillip Morris is blunt about illicit personal traits gays share with straights and that define our era. Importantly, the filmmakers don't equate gay with subversive.
Tamara Drewe is one of Stephen Frears' deadlies -- like his awful 2002 Liam -- where his proven skill with actors doesn't overcome a dumb concept.
Children should not be exposed to this lurid display of helplessness and pessimism -- and adult viewers should be wary of the nihilistic indulgence.
Like one of those fake-smart, middlebrow TV shows, the speciousness of The Social Network is disguised by topicality. It's really a movie excusing Hollywood ruthlessness.
Jonze's breakthrough should prove as timeless as O. Henry's classic tale.
It's got miracle-worker actors, but only a miracle-worker director could pull off this drivel.
Efron cries tears the way a cheerleader waves pom-poms.
Actors are paid to be embarrassing, and audiences pay to get embarrassed. That's the lesson to learn from Dinner for Schmucks, an idiot-comedy for idiots.
Fascinating yet unsatisfactory.
Life During Wartime might be the toughest American movie of 2010. Its audacity confirms Solondz's ingenuity and thematic focus.
It offends one's cinematic and political sensibilities just as carelessly as Syriana, Green Zone or Inglourious Basterds.
Despicable Me works as adult comedy in the same intelligent sense as Dr. Seuss rhymes.
Like Grand Theft Auto's quasi-cinematic extension of noir and action-flick plots, Inception manipulates the digital audience's delectation for relentless subterfuge.
Cholodenko's films always falter through their obvious, self-congratulatory point-making.
Love Ranch ("inspired by a true story") should have been satirical. Instead, it's just accidentally hilarious.
Despite its horror movie premise, the Twilight series has become an ADHD sedative.
Their unsentimental portraits of platoon life match harsh deployment to fast, gentle camaraderie.
Cheerful and surprisingly heartfelt.
Winterbottom is in Mike Figgis mode, offering grossly violent filmnoir clichés, made of punching-bag-face make-up, gratuitous sex and Dark Knight nihilism...
It embarrasses just about every other piece of filmmaking around.
There's no kinetic rhythm, no From Paris With Love energy or craft, no Jonah Hex wit -- only a distorted, distended James Bondish marathon chase.
It reexamines assumptions of good and evil-morality tale vs, trite entertainment-by confronting the hideous compromises people make with social conventions and their own desperation.
Toy Story 3 is so besotted with brand names and product-placement that it stops being about the innocent pleasures of imagination -- the usefulness of toys -- and strictly celebrates consumerism.
Swinton always attempts bold milestones, but I Am Love makes one long to go back to the old landmarks.

There's little distance between X-Men: Apocalypse and the films of Chinese director Jia Zhangke. Although their audiences are different (juvenile thrill-seekers and art-movie devotees), the films appeal to the same grim taste for catastrophe.

Stonewall Uprising commits an unfortunate revisionism: Every person interviewed in the doc refocuses that legendary civil disobedience at the Stonewall Inn as a homogeneously white, mostly male memory. Stonewall Uprising's history is gentrified history.
It is more proof that the influence of TV-style superficiality -- undramatic pacing, routine imagery -- has ruined the imagination of both filmgoers and filmmakers.
Araki discovers modern morality within the blueeyed ruins of a Hollister model the same way archeologists uncover ancient totems.
Joel Schumacher's talent exceeds his ambition in Twelve.
The Expendables is third-rate.
Snyder's wildlife adventure returns him to genius: extreme, dream-like action cinema that expresses his pop-art faith.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger continues the selfishness and lack of faith that in Manhattan once seemed to observe moral decay, and Hannah and Her Sisters became a symptom of. There's been no real progress since...
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: James Franco's now tiresome androgyny (so soon?) asks for wink-nod approval of Ginsberg's hero status without adequately delineating Ginsberg's personality or the emotional tensions of the late-'50s era.
Money Never Sleeps isn't an epic masterpiece like Stone's World Trade Center, but it's often amazingly vivid.
Easy A is now frontrunner for worst film of 2010.

Romanek has a genuine, acquired understanding of pop's prevarications. He means to avoid triviality and bring emotional and visual gravity to the experience of youth, yet doesn't seem to grasp that Ishiguro's concept is daft.
The Town is nearly as ludicrous as [Affleck's] debut Gone Baby Gone -- another poison pen letter to Beantown.

If critics and fanboys weren't suckers for simplistic nihilism and high-pressure marketing, Afterlife would be universally acclaimed as a visionary feat, superior to Inception and Avatar on every level.
Hideaway continues Ozon's brave apostasy that procreation (parenthood) is our nature.
If this kind of selfconscious cinema junk is to be enjoyed, it can only be enjoyed by morons.
Clooney's still on his anti-American kick, sentimentalizing the corruption that appeals to cynical film critics who fall for his forced, noxious "charm."
From one great director to another, a Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop pays tribute to the Coens by improving their earlier immature work.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: My Dog Tulip restores human feeling to animation, a post-Pixar miracle.
Takers refines a genre that has been hollowed-out by the cold repetitions of such cliché movies as Soderbergh's Oceans franchise...
If you accurately described each scene, you'd have a book of poetry. That's how detailed and vivid are The Milk of Sorrow's rhythms.
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: New rule: Only one decapitation per ancient action movie.
Mesrine's attempt to rival Hollywood crime movies' magnum force -- either through B-movie precision or A-movie elaborateness -- fails.
Think what Hannah Arendt could have made of this footage? Typical of contemporary advocacy journalism, Hersonski doesn't know what to do with this outrageous material except show it.
Cube may not have seen René Clair's 1931 lottery masterpiece Le Million, but, as a film impresario, he captures some of its culturally-specific charm.
The Tillman Story is another example of how contemporary journalism and documentary-making have lost credibility.
Wright's speed and humor are authentic and irresistible. Let's hope that's not all his admirers see.
The Other Guys just goes all over the place; stay tuned to see if McKay goes anywhere.
Frankie and Alice is the kind of grandstanding that exposes an actress' pathetic dependence on approval by others.
Isn't really as good as the underrated 1980s diptych, Breakin' and the superb Breakin' 2: Electric Boogalo...
Right now, Portman commands the cineplexes as surrogate for misguided, self-pitying filmmakers.

The Help demonstrates the conned intelligence of the "post-racial" and "postblack" Obama era, where the anxieties of unequal yet mutually beneficial black-white relationships are conveniently, speciously, put behind us.
It is easily the best American movie of this corrupted summer.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cowboys and Aliens is an uninspired, third-rate rehash of Western and monster movie lore. It turns genre into formula.
If the title suggests soap opera rather than political history, that's part of Ruiz's game -- but it's also why this art project feels overlong for its purpose.

The film disastrously focuses on Uday's outrages and does so without any moral perspective. "Rape, torture, disembowelment, killing, drinking, drugs and decadence" is practically the film's synopsis. Madness is its misjudged rationale.
It enhances a sense of the world rather than peddling distraction from it.
Me and My Gal justifies the loftiest standards of realism and entertainment.
When all these bland Marvel Comics franchise movies blur together in memory, it won't prove that they amounted to one great epic master narrative, but that they're all indistinguishable.
Now that the Harry Potter series is over, maybe the truth can be realized: This has been the dullest franchise in the history of movie franchises.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Although this is an adaptation of the A.A. Milne tales first published in 1926, it unleashes an essential quality of dreaming -- and of cinema.
Evading the issue of what used to be called "yellow journalism," Morris' depraved method prevents us from ever getting out of this swamp.

By avoiding contemplation about the emotional nature of its clanging, morphing, warring creatures ... Bay and executive producer Steven Spielberg accommodate the insensitivity that characterizes post-9/11 culture.
The humanist opposite to Hollywood's self-congratulatory snark.
Kasdan and company miss the opportunity to connect Elizabeth's venality to the greed and materialism that her pop consumer students absorb daily.
The F/X of Hal creating objects out of his ring's green light are successfully, modestly fantastic. Such professionalism needn't resort to dumb stereotyping.
Rossi's own Times bias gives Page One a romantic, rather than journalistic, slant.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Pandering and illogical, Super 8's plot makes no demands on viewers' intelligence.
Ovredal's man-to-monster compositions alternately recall Tiananmen Square or the destruction of New York's WTC, and then evoke the obligation of witnessing such deeds.
The entire film is a hackneyed exercise.
Thewlis' great talent has been MIA since Mike Leigh's 1993 Naked but here he delivers a caricature of British cultural audacity that is so outrageously vivid it deserves the term Dickensian.
Beginners is not culturally astute.
Sexism may be inseparable from the imperatives of male aggression. 30 Minutes or Less ridicules this...
Rejoice and Shout offers the most magnificent, heroic examples of art to be found in any movie so far this year.
One Day is neither comedy nor satire; it uses numerous narrative gimmicks to avoid the fact of its humdrum banality.
Sfar rescues Gainsbourg from hipsters' self-satisfied claims.
Evoking the forgotten meanings of action-adventure films (pre-Tarantino) is enough to make The Eagle a distinctive, if minor, film.

Money Monster (also the name of Gates's program) pretends to expose Wall Street chicanery at the same time as critiquing opportunistic television. Who do Clooney, director Jodie Foster, and lead screenwriter Jamie Linden think they are?

Captain America and Iron Man almost represent the schism that now divides American voters, politicians, and pundits. I say "almost," because the film...doesn't inspire reflection upon the dire seriousness of our current ideological civil war.

The Measure of a Man...charts a global unease in the case of a working-class white male trying to stay afloat in Europe's unsteady economy...Brizé's unplotted, naturalistic style highlights a common man's series of on-going indignities.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hanks has moved forward - as an artist must, and as American foreign policy should have - toward reconciliation. A Hologram for the King lets modern technological commitment...lead toward Clay's rediscovery of his humanity.

Grant and Famuyiwa, with their dependence on famous names and talking heads, prove incapable of achieving character depth, atmosphere, or intellectual nuance. Instead, this turning-point cultural event falls into the maw of TV sensationalism.

Bercot's best irony is the film's fleet, incisive style - not docudrama but emotional precision in the composition, editing, and perfectly pitched humane performances (including Catherine Deneuve and Benoit Magimel at their compassionate best).

Norwegian director Joachim Trier makes his first American film with Louder than Bombs, but shows off the same morose affectations as in his previous work, Reprise and Oslo, August 31st (a not bad but still lesser update of Louis Malle's The Fire Within).
In Demolition, director Jean-Marc Vallée goes for the same slick, scattershot existentialism as in his previous films, The Dallas Buyers Club and Wild.

Abraham ignores cultural specifics that could illuminate the society that produced a figure like Hiram King Williams, who enjoyed his cultural heritage and took his masculine freedom as brazenly as Miles Davis did.

Miles Ahead is held together by Cheadle's regard for its subject, which clearly emboldened him, as a first-time director, to attempt filmmaking as complex and original as Davis's musical compositions and improvisation.

In this age of petty Marvels, most comic-book movies merely perpetrate fantasies of power, but Snyder, enacting his personal aesthetic, braves a film that examines those fantasies. He boldly challenges popular culture's current decay.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In Tricked (Verhoeven calls it "My 14 1/2, like Fellini's 8 1/2"), the character-driven story still relies on a visual effect - the exposed behind-the-scenes process of filmmaking.
The clichés in Eddie the Eagle are upfront, but these are also verities; they are organic to the story and essential to the example that Eddie represents.
We desperately need a reminder that the film industry still comprises human beings with recognizable histories - and souls.

Yes, it's claptrap, but not entirely dismissable, because of Nichols's compelling grasp of two authentic aspects of American experience: the parochial white South and our continued indulgence of the youth cult.
Me Him Her (the title eschews any punctuation that would separate people) expands the rom-com into social compassion.

Cohen's burlesque (raunchy sex gags so blatant they're surreal) is his most hilarious and effective mode, but half-jokes about government surveillance expose a double standard; he's either politically ignorant or dishonest.
It takes a nincompoop like Howard to imagine depth in this silliness.
Puiu's a skillful widescreen filmmaker, but he's also an urban snob who finds farm animals backward and funny.

Terence Davies' Sunset Song, a personalized tale about young Christine Guthrie (Agyness Deyn) growing up in rural Scotland just before World War One, is also a national epic about one's connection to a culture through language and the land.
Usually movies this slick and contrived have a shiny, Hollywood look, but Our Idiot Brother's unslick look is dreadful. It lacks the professionalism of mumblecore.
More than a storyteller, always a poet, Jean-Luc Godard continues to challenge how movies function and how we look at them.
Tribe's music takes a backseat to power struggle and personality conflict.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Telling a bad joke twice doesn't mean it was any good the first time.
Its plot, ripped off from The Amityville Horror, shows so little psychological or occult logic that it exposes its own sheer dumbness as just a series of spookings.
It's bloody but without menstrual awareness; just as its musical pretext neglects to express genuine feminine trauma or yearning.
It's another signpost on Ozon's apprenticeship toward cinema mastery.
Paul brings back all that is consequential through an ingenious spoof of taken-for-granted sci-fi lore.
Typically, The Lincoln Lawyer uses black pop culture to bring urban consciousness and street cunning to a Hollywood film's slick surface.

Unlike those indie directors whose feel-good, P.C. claptrap predictably gets praised by the very people it flatters, Mendelsohn makes suburban poetry that opposes the way middle-class film culture likes to fantasize itself.
A less good doc than last year's more honest and insightful Smash His Camera, about paparazzo Ron Galella.
Beneath the silly premise is a consistent depiction of military performance, duty and sacrifice that is so unexpected that the film's genre transforms from fantasy to war movie.
Too bad Hardwicke didn't adapt The Scarlet Letter -- better yet, she could have transformed the asinine Easy A.
It is faint praise to note that Tuesday, After Christmas is the most approachable of recent Romanian releases. Still, it's neither revealing nor compelling.
A remarkably evenhanded history.
Kiarostami has become the new Kieslowski, an emigrant to Western Europe whose pretentiousness embarrasses the whole concept of art cinema-as proven by Certified Copy.
Weerasethakul is, in fact, the blandest of visionaries. His picturesque images lack the intensity found in the great folkloric artist-filmmaker Julián Hernández.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Because Scorsese is not a Continental sophisticate like Malle, but an American boomer pop artist, Lebowitz's forays into ideas and history are not his forte.
Bresson exemplified 20th-century ecumenical intelligence that is much out of fashion today, yet remains singular and powerful.
movie_title: Diary of a Country Priest (Journal d'un curé de campagne) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: Beauvois deliberately avoids Nationalist reproach, seeking commiseration that goes deeper than the acquiescence for which French liberals are typically known.
Unknown touches on the crisis, but director Jaume- Collet Serra and his screenwriters aren't serious enough or the action adept enough to fully articulate it.
It's a blatant exploitation film (what Variety calls "an actioner"), yet its obviousness, keyed to Levesque's squared-circle appeal, is humorous.
Gnomic imagery like this is an arty-artifice, based in sociological condescension.
The humorous tangents of Just Go With It are testaments to the fine art of improvisation and of comedy that doesn't take itself overly seriously.
Poetry isn't quite in the class of Kurosawa's Stray Dog, but Lee's domestic-social drama certainly evinces some of Kurosawa's... well, poetry.
By trashing fairytale propriety, Green and McBride personalize the genre enthusiasm of the Star Wars generation.
Worse than film school formula, Arthur's transparently the product of some powerful Hollywood agents responsible for foisting Brand on American culture.
Once again, after the obnoxious The Informant and insufferable Hereafter, Matt Damon uses movies to explain the world to audiences who just want to be entertained.
Imminently watchable, Hanna suggests a thinking-person's Kick-Ass.
Indulging Rodriguez's ugliness limits the image of gay life and gay culture to negativity and grotesquerie.
It's so rare to see a film with such a great subject that the flaws of The First Grader are totally forgivable.
Depp's caricature is so far past its expiration date that it forces speculation about the actor's own movie stardom.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The groupie-like celebration of Allen's doubled-up cultural insecurity and ambition represents a global degradation of culture standards.
It's an overly contrived jumble, trying out too many comic ideas that eventually swamp the central subject of what a modern young woman expects regarding friendship, courtship and marriage.

​Neighbors 2 is designed, rather cleverly, to tickle indulgent parents as well as self-indulgent kids (picking off two target audiences at once). Rogen and director Nicholas Stoller satirize outdated morality and pitiable decorum.
It is far beyond the juvenile time-jumping in Blue Valentine or the old-fogey show tunes nostalgia of any random Nora Ephron movie.
A full-fledged exercise in the sensuality of genetic similarity and different shades of family sensibility.
Jumping the Broom is an in-law comedy with soul.

A small but excellent cast supports McKellen in what is a beautiful and intelligent film.
Ludicrously long at this running time -- even seven minutes would have overstated its case -- Marathon truly lives up to its name.
Fun despite it's occasional slow points.

The gritty nature of the world of DC is worth the price of admission.

Andy Serkis hits it out of the park with Breathe.
Aaron Sorkin's directorial debut is a triumph.
Brie Larson's feature directorial debut is a triumphant and enchanting film.

It will easily delight genre fans, but its ability to maintain a moral center and its complex character development will speak to mainstream viewers, too.

The effect? A super-fun, bananas-weird tale of thrilling heroics and life-defining friendships animated with collage, line art, paint, Sixties liquid-light effects, and realistic botanical and animal sketches.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Along with a lot of laughs, Moonwalkers offers a lovingly critical take on pop culture, touching on themes of patriotism and film industry pomp, without getting cynical.
Flirting with magical realism, it has an otherworldly beauty that provides one more lens through which to see the film. There are many thematic interpretations to expound on here.
The film develops a unique lushness, without losing track of the story or that clever sense of humor that marks so many good gangster flicks.
The ghost story makes for a fun and creepy horror movie -- plenty to call the film a success. But there's definitely more to it for anyone choosing to look closer.
Head of the direction duties, James Foley, strings it together well, making it harmonise like the musical piece it has succeeded to be.
It's a film so well paced with a message so relevant that it deserves an audience bigger than what it got and it deserves more of an emotional impact than will resonant throughout.
A truly individual, dedicated concept that pulls through by seamlessly flowing in perfect harmonic construction.
What you have here is a very solid film that zings as well as zigs and zags to keep you guessing.

This documentary helps immortalise a man with a message of freedom, change, and achievement - one which may have been forgotten.
A distant attempt at something more personal.
Everything a sequel should be in terms of better but distractingly a reboot that means its predecessor should be wiped away. Two versions of the same thing by the same people is too many.

movie_review_blurb: The '80s-centric atmosphere means that viewers over a certain age will probably connect to the material to a greater extent than their younger counterparts. In fact, the nostalgia factor might be enough for some people to overlook Adventureland's flaws.

Every guy has watched an action film and wondered when we'd get to the good stuff, but from minute one we're given "the good stuff," but it's just not executed well enough, and the film is too kitschy to really be enjoyed.
Sam Raimi returns to his Evil Dead roots with this white-knuckle horror flick that has the ability to scare the pants off you one moment then cause the giggles the next.
